tickets.summary: canonical references: imprecise language about software handling and errors
tickets.description:
Section #SACR discusses encoding and processing of canonical references.  However, there are some suspicious statements:

1) "When an application encounters a canonical reference as the value of cRef attribute, it follows a sequence of specific steps to transform it into a URI reference." -- We seem to be describing how we think hypothetical software operates.  I suggest changing "it follows" to "it might follow" or something less cumbersome like "these Guidelines recommend that it follow".

2) "It is an error to reference more matched substrings than are produced by the regular expression." -- Unless one or more of the various schema langauges generated by Roma/Byzantium can detect this, it seems we mean to say that it is not TEI-conformant to encode a document in this way.  I suggest changing to say "It is not conformant to these Guidelines to reference [. . .]".  Also adjust the wording in the following sentence ("would produce an error").

posts.text:
1) Change to "[. . .] of the @cRef attribute, it might follow the following sequence of steps to transform it into URI reference:"

tickets.description: According to its desc, `<add>` "contains letters, words, or phrases inserted in the text by an author, scribe, annotator, or corrector". A bit later in the current tagdoc there is a note contradicting this ("The `<add> element should not be used for additions made by editors or encoders. In these cases, either the <corr> or <supplied> element should be used.`") This inconsistency reflects a long-standing debate both in the TEI community and beyond. The original TEI position, reflected in the `<desc>`, was to avoid taking a position, but subsequent users have taken the view (reflected in the note) that markup should always mark only what's visible on the page. I think we need to revise the text to make clear that both options are tenable, but that projects may well wish to be explicit about which they prefer. Certainly we should not continue to contradict ourselves.

posts.text:
- **status**: open --> closed-fixed
- **assigned_to**: BODARD Gabriel
- **Priority**: 5 --> 1(low)

tickets.description:
This ticket arises out action on a now-closed Feature Request:

http://sourceforge.net/p/tei/feature-requests/428/

The Nelson and Baxter bibliographical items in this example:

http://teijenkins.hcmc.uvic.ca/job/TEIP5/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html#index-egXML-d49e39468

are purposely encoded with no extraneous whitespace, in accordance with arguments by John McCaskey and others that whitespace in elements such as `<bibl>` is significant and should not be discarded by a processor. However, the Guidelines rendering code automatically pretty-prints them in indented format, adding whitespace where there shouldn't be any. We should decide whether this is important or not; if it is, then rendering of such elements in examples should be tweaked so that the original whitespace content is exactly preserved.

posts.text: From Providence meeting: Action on HC and SR to test the use of @xml:space to solve this specific problem, and to see whether that’s the correct solution in the long term.

tickets.summary: remnant of P4 in discussion of @resp?
tickets.description:
Paragraph <http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/PH.html\#id2657020> starts with:

"As these examples show, the field of application of the @resp attributes varies from element to element. In some cases, it applies to the content of the element \(corr, ex, and supplied\); in others it applies to the value of a particular attribute \(sic, abbr, del, etc.\). "

Hasn't this changed in P5, as the @corr and @expan attributes have been replaced with <corr> and <expan> elements in P5? Besides that, it's unclear to me what attribute of <del> is meant...

posts.text: The sentence you quote is just plain wrong. There is no case where  @resp gives responsibility for some attribute value. On the other hand, it isn't the content for which responsibility is being given, but the categorisation of that content implied by the particular element, On balance I think it's better just to remove th sentence, pending a rewrite of the whole chapter. tickets.description:
The definition of the <age> tag contains a swag of Western assumptions about how age is calculated. The standard should at least raise a warning flag about it's use in East Asian cultures and global scenarios in which East Asian individuals are likely to be encountered.

A good reference for this is http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East\_Asian\_age\_reckoning

posts.text:
Sorry, I don't see where the <age> element has any assumptions about how it is calculated. It seems woefully underspecified to me. AFAIK there is no discussion of it at all in chapter 13. The tagdoc just says “specified the age of a person”.

Is it used like the age= attribute of <person>? If so, it has to do with sociologists groupings of persons by age, not with the current date minus the date of birth. You say “\[t\]he standard should at least raise a warning flag about it's use in East Asian cultures”. I presume by “standard” you mean the Guidelines. But what warning flag do you mean? This element isn’t used by East Asian cultures in general, it is used by encoding projects, which may have a need to record someone’s age. Are you aware of projects that find it important to record the traditional 1+lunar-new-years age instead of \(or in addition to\) the modern age, and have found <age> insufficient to that purpose?

Perhaps the Guidelines should give an example of encoding a person’s age in the traditional system?
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #186 <age> and Western cultural assumptions

posts.text:
You're right Syd.

I ran across this when conducting groundwork for the possible digitisation of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justice\_Erima\_Harvey\_Northcroft\_Tokyo\_War\_Crimes\_Trial\_Collection . In particular I'm looking at how to store the authority control information, since it seems like that the authority control information for this project will be kept distinct from our other authority control information. Since name and age are the identifying information given in most Western legal scenarios that I'm aware of, I'd assumed that name and age were the key  authority control information available in this project.
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #186 <age> and Western cultural assumptions

posts.text: This a bit too cryptic for me.  Can you explain a bit more what you actually want \_done\_? I understand that east asian cultures work slightly differently when calculating age, but how does this affect the definition "supplies a numeric code representing the age or age group". Or are you worried by the example text of "under 20 in the early eighties"?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #186 <age> and Western cultural assumptions

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard

posts.subject: #186 <age> and Western cultural assumptions

tickets.description: The note at the end of the of the element description for <back> is not at all a useful note, and it raises more questions than it answers: "The content model of back matter is identical to that of front matter, reflecting the facts of cultural history." I don't think it contributes usefully to the element description and should either be expanded or (probably preferably) deleted.

posts.text:
This note appears to be a shortened and confusing version of what appears in the prose of 4.7:

> Conventions vary as to which elements are grouped as back matter and which as front. For example, some books place the table of contents at the front, and others at the back. Even title pages may appear at the back of a book as well as at the front. The content model for back and front elements are therefore identical.

This dates back at least as far as P4, and so does the note. I agree that it's unhelpful as it is, but it is worth making the point that back and front have a close relationship and identical content models. I vote that the note be expanded to make it comprehensible, rather than deleted.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #702 Note in element description of <back>

posts.text: Yes, the 4.7 note is much clearer, and I agree that with a note more along the lines of the 4.7 version, the information is quite useful--so, I change my thinking from preferring deletion to preferring a richer note along these lines.

tickets.summary: reports and asserts being inappropriately separated
tickets.description:
Chapter 22.4.4 has an example of a <constraintSpec scheme="isoschematron"> that has a single <constraint> child, which in turn has two <sch:report> children. \(This is the "activemutual" example.\) However, I put a similar construct into the 'relatedItem' tagdoc \(at r7409\), and the ISO Schematron file that \`roma\` generates is now invalid: there are duplicates of the xml:id= value "relatedItem-constraint-targetorcontent". This is because two separate <sch:pattern> elements are generated \(each with 1 child <sch:rule>\), rather than one <sch:pattern> with two <sch:rule> children. Since the two are different \(only the first <sch:rule> in a pattern whose context is found fires\), the ODD author should have control over this. Only one <sch:pattern> should be generated per <constraint>.

I note, BTW, that the 'relation' tagdoc, which has the actual "activemutual" Schematron test used by the Guidelines, uses two separate <constraintSpec> elements to avoid this problem.

posts.text: Fair point. I have re-written the schematron extraction code to group asserts and reports together where the ODD has them in the same constraint.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #187 reports and asserts being inappropriately separated

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #187 reports and asserts being inappropriately separated

tickets.description: According to http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-att.global.html , @xml:lang should always be used on the outermost element \(TEI\), but I have not yet found this used in any of the examples in P5.  It would also be good if this strong recommendation to use @xml:lang were included in the definition of TEI: http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-TEI.html

posts.text: Actually, now that I think about it, it might be better to recommend use @xml:lang on both <teiHeader> and <body> to clarify that the metadata and document are likely to be in different languages.  In this case, there would be no need to have @xml:lang on <TEI>
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #91 TEI@xml:lang

posts.text:
Kevin raises two issues:
1\) Examples do not show xml:lang= on <TEI>
2\) Guidelines should recommend xml:lang= on <teiHeader> and <body> \[instead?\]
I'll address this individually.

1\) I agree wholeheartedly that this is a gross oversight, and think an xml:lang= should be added to most if not all 23 example <TEI> elements.

2\) This is a very reasonable thought for those cases where the language of the metadata is in large part different than the language of the content. However, putting xml:lang= on <TEI> is
a\) equally reasonable for those cases where the language of the metadata is in large part the same as the language of the content, and
b\) that which Council voted the Guidelines should recommend.
c\) caters to systems that look at the language of the root element to decide what to do.

So I suggest that the Guidelines continue to recommend xml:lang= on <TEI>. However, a sentence  that explicitly mentions that putting a separate xml:lang= on <teiHeader> or <body> or both is a great idea. An example, too.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #91 TEI@xml:lang

posts.text: Agreed that this needs better documentation and exemplification. In progress\!
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #91 TEI@xml:lang

tickets.description:
In providing metadata about a TEI document in teiHeader, it would be useful to be able to indicate the language\(s\) used in the text \(not the metadata\).  If an entire document is in one language, you could simply use body@xml:lang.  If a text is mostly in one language but has occasional blocks or spans in another language, you could also use body@xml:lang, with @xml:lang on child elements as needed.

However, if a document contains text in various languages, yet the encoding is not in-depth enough to differentiate them at the block or span level yet you still want to indicate languages used, there is no way to indicate this.  @xml:lang will not accept more than one language code, so you couldn't simply use <body xml:lang="en-CA fr-CA" to indicate a bilingual publication.  \(Note that BCP 47 allows this, but P5 will not.\)

So I request allowing multiple language codes on @xml:lang.  If this loosening of the allowed content of @xml:lang for what is perhaps the only need for it, then I would like to have textLang available in the header module \(not sure which element it would be a child of\) for indicating the language\(s\) used in the body of a document.

posts.text: I don't understand--isn't the langUsage element sufficient for this purpose? That's what it's intended for. In any case, allowing multiple values for @xml:lang is at odds with the W3C specification: http://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-xml-20081126/\#sec-lang-tag and I think it would open up a huge can of worms and break a lot of existing code \(that expects @xml:lang to contain a single valid language identifer\)
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

posts.text: I just looked at http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/bcp/bcp47.txt but I don't see where it sanctions using multiple tokens within an @xml:lang value? Even in XHTML, @lang is constrained to be a single name token.
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

posts.text:
In 4.1, it says:

The 'mul' \(Multiple\) primary language subtag SHOULD NOT be used whenever the protocol allows the separate tags for multiple languages, as is the case for the Content-Language header in HTTP.

So if we just change the datatype for @xml:lang, we could do something like:

<text xml:lang="en-CA fr-CA"><\!-- \[text here\] --></text>
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

posts.text: Right, we could change the datatype this way. But it would violate the W3C's intent for @xml:lang, which I'll grant is not spelled out extremely clearly. It's certainly the case that for XHTML, @xml:lang cannot take more than one language value \(http://www.w3.org/TR/i18n-html-tech-lang/\#ri20030112.224623362\). I'm not \*sure\* that it would XML-unkosher for TEI documents to differ, but I strongly suspect so.
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

posts.text: I agree with David: \(a\) the requirement for documenting the use of different languages is supported by the existing langUsage element \(b\) the fact that xml:lang is global means that the actual language used at any point \(at any level\) within a TEI document can be documented correctly \(c\) changing the datatype of xml:lang to permit multiple  values would be at best inadvisable. If there are particular applications which prefer multiple values \(rather than multiple elements\) there is nothing to prevent their being generated from the langUsage element.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #92 undifferentiated multilingual text

tickets.summary: RELAX NG validation of RNG of macro.anyXML
tickets.description:
When I build P5, \`make validate\` issues \`jing -t p5odds.rng Source/Guidelines/en/guidelines-en.xml \`, which gives me an error:
.../P5/Source/Specs/macro.anyXML.xml:19:48: error: found attribute "ns", but no attributes allowed here

I don't believe the error is correct. I think ISO 19757-2:2003 Annex A makes it pretty clear that ns= is an allowed attribute on <rng:name>. \(Line 220 of the schema if you extract it, at the top of page 28 of the standard itself.\)

The definition of <rng:name> in p5odds.rng does not have 'common-atts'. Makes me think p5odds.rng was built against an old or incorrect version of RELAX NG.

Just a guess.

— Syd

tickets.description:
There is some confusion as to whether or not the @material attribute on <sourceDesc> is or is not limited to a predetermined list of values. The language in the index is pretty clear that it is \("Values Are"\), but a search through the rng schema for Manuscript Description output by Roma doesn't indicate such a limitation, and such a restriction does not make sense.

http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-supportDesc.html

If the TEI wants to claim that the manuscript description element can be used for text-bearing objects other than codex manuscripts \(papyrus scrolls, inscriptions on stone, tattoos, what have you\), this limitation \(if it exists\) needs to be lifted. Alternatively, if it's a problem in the text of the index \("Values Are" should be "Suggested Values Include"\), it needs to be changed.

posts.text: These are indeed just suggested values, not a closed value list when I look at the spec. And just typing anything into @material, my document still validates.  I'm guessing, therefore that it is a bug in the transformation of the Guidelines which says 'Values Are' rather than 'Suggested Values Included'.

tickets.description:
In P5, 16.1.2 gives nice examples of how to encode complicated footnotes assuming there is no footnote reference in the text \(like a superscript number\).  You can either use "implicit pointing", putting the note element at the point of reference, or use "explicit" pointing, with a ptr element at the point of reference.

But what if there is a superscript number?  Should you use ptr or ref?  My inclination is to use ref, similar to the second TOC example in 4.5 \(which has page number references, unlike the first TOC example\).  It seems to me that footnote references are such a common encoding need that P5 should be explicit about how to do this \(with an example\).

posts.text: The superscript number is  something about which opinions vary: it's rather like the numbering or bullets of a list, or the quote marks of a quotation. I am not sure that everyone would agree that encoding them  explicitly \(with ref\) rather than implying them \(with ptr\) was a common encoding need but it's certainly an option  that should be suggested in the text, if it isn't already.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #94 footnote references: ptr or ref?

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #94 footnote references: ptr or ref?

posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #94 footnote references: ptr or ref?

posts.text: At rev \#6937 I've revised the text a bit to licence the explicit encoding of the point of attachment siglum, and added a simple example. Syd's example points from the note to the footnote reference, which doesn't seem quite the right way round.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #94 footnote references: ptr or ref?

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-accepted
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #94 footnote references: ptr or ref?

posts.text:
My apologies; I missed this when it was initially closed back in Nov, and just now am noticing it when Kevin mentioned it in private e-mail for a different reason.

> Syd's example points from the note to the footnote reference, which doesn't
> seem quite the right way round.

I agree that it does not seem, at first blush, like the right way round. But it is what the TEI Guidelines explicitly recommended in P2 \(6.8.1\), P3 \(6.8.1\), P4 \(6.8.1\), and P5 \(3.8.1\). To suggest the reverse -- as has now been codified at r6937 -- seems like a step backwards, a step away from consistency, harmony, and what little interoperability there may be in the TEI universe.

For years I have told people that it doesn't really matter whether the anchor \(typically a content element like <name>, or an attachment flag encoded as <anchor>, <ptr>, or <ref>\) points to the note or vice-versa. But since the TEI Guidelines recommend that the <note> point to the <anchor> \(or whatever\), that is the way they should do it. The logic was that because the TEI Guidelines chose one of these two essentially equivalent methods, everyone would use it, and we'd all share the benefits of doing things the same way.

Of course, for those who like belts and suspenders, the anchor can also point back to the note. \(Using target= or corresp=.\)
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #94 footnote references: ptr or ref?

tickets.description:
p. 445

Text: "An organization is not the same thing as a list or group of people"

Comment: Category mistake.

Suggestion: "An organization is not the same thing as a group of people"

posts.text:
I don't think that this is a mistake. What's implied here is "An organization is not the same thing as a list [of people] or group of people." 

The sentence that comes just a bit later, though, confuses things:
 
"For example, a sports team might be defined in terms of its membership (a listPerson), its fixtures (a listPlace), its geographical affiliation (a placeName), or any combination of these."

We've just said that a list of people is not sufficient to make an organization, so perhaps "defined" is misleadingly applied here. I propose instead:

"The <org> describing a sports team might contain children defining its its membership (a listPerson), its fixtures (a listPlace), its geographical affiliation (a placeName), or any combination of these."
posts.author: rwelzenb
posts.subject: #557 Category mistake

posts.text: I agree that "defined" is not good and that your alternative is more precise, but I still don't see how an organization can be a list (of persons or organizations), unless "list" used in the very loose sense of "a number of". However, this is hardly a major issue.
posts.author: jenspetersen
posts.subject: #557 Category mistake

posts.text:
Maybe just change defined to described?  An org element isnt obligatory is it?


Sent from Samsung Mobile

The sentence that comes just a bit later, though, confuses things:

"For example, a sports team might be defined in terms of its membership (a listPerson), its fixtures (a listPlace), its geographical affiliation (a placeName), or any combination of these."

We've just said that a list of people is not sufficient to make an organization, so perhaps "defined" is misleadingly applied here. I propose instead:

tickets.summary: cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output
tickets.description:
== Summary ==

If a table contains in its first row a cell which spans multiple columns, running the XSLT version 2 stylesheets on an XML document conforming to a vanilla TEI schema results in incorrect LaTeX code.

== Versions ==

Ubuntu 10.4

$ dpkg-query -W tei-p5-xsl2
tei-p5-xsl2     5.30

== How to Reproduce ==

1\. Download the attached zip file.

2\. Unzip.

3\. Edit the Makefile so that STYLE points to where your copy of the XSLT 2 version of the LaTeX stylesheet is.

4\. Execute 

$ make test.pdf
$ make test2.pdf

== Actual Results ==

Making either test.xml or test2.xml results in the following error at the stage of running LaTeX on the output of the XSL transformation:

\! Extra alignment tab has been changed to \cr.

== Expected Results ==

There should be no error. That is, correct LaTeX code should be generated.

== Observations ==

The test.xml and test2.xml files provided to illustrate the bug contain two different ways of encoding a table. I've searched the P5 Guidelines but was not able to find a directive as to how "merged cells" are supposed to be handled to conform to P5. \(I've also searched previous bug reports and did a general Google search.\) Let me explain. According to the LaTeX model, if one uses \multicolumn to make a cell span multiple columns, then the cells which are merged with this cell are not encoded separately. So if a table has a total of 3 columns and a cell spans 3 columns then this row will contain only one cell, the one encoded by \multicolumn. Other table models require that merged cells be encoded as separate empty cells.

So I've tried both models without knowing which one is mandated by P5. At any rate, neither model works:

1\. When processing test.xml, the stylesheet determines the number of columns by counting the number of cell elements. It ignores the presence of the "cols" attribute so it incorrectly computes a table of 2 cells. When the cells in the first row are processed, it results in a row of 3 cells: one regular cell plus the \multicolumn command which adds 2 cells.

2\. When processing test2.xml, the stylesheet determines the number of columns by counting the number of cell elements. In this case, there is an empty cell standing in for the cell which ends up being merged with the <cell cols="2"> cell. So the number of columns computed is correct: this is a table of 3 columns. However, when the first row is processed, the stylesheet produces a row of 4 cells: one regular cell plus the \multicolumn command which adds 2 cells and the empty cell at the end of the row results in another cell in the LaTeX output.

3\. The file test3.xml was added to show that if:

a\) one follows the LaTeX model for encoding spanning cells \(i.e. cells whose space is taken up by a cell spanning multiple columns are NOT encoded in the XML\), and

b\) spanning cells appear ONLY ELSEWHERE than the first row,

then the LaTeX output is correct, as far as column and cell accounting is concerned anyway. \(There seem to be a presentation issue but I'm not going to investigate that now.\)

I've grepped through the Test files bundled in tei-p5-test but was not able to find a case with a table containing a cell spanning multiple columns.

4\. The file test4.xml was added to show a partial workaround: use a preamble attribute to manually create a correct table preamble. Unfortunately this attribute requires the schema to be customized.

Moreover, the preamble attribute is not enough to produce a correct table. I noticed the color of the multicolumn cell in test4.pdf is incorrect. If I add "\)\{\columncolor\{label\}\}" in the second argument of the \multicolumn command generated by the stylesheets, this fixes the color.

5\. The presence or absence of the "cols" attribute on the "table" element has no effect whatsoever.

posts.text: files illustrating the problem

posts.subject: #194 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

posts.text: I'm the one who submitted this. I really wished sourceforge would prevent me from accidentally submitting anonymously\! \*grumble\*

posts.subject: #194 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

posts.text:
I have fixed this problem, more or less. the "less" is that multicolumn entries are now centered. I am not sure how to handle their width.

The TEI definitely follows the table model whereby the spanned cells do not appear. so your first example is correct

To appear in the next release in a day or two

tickets.description:
p. 435

Text: "We envisage three basic types of users and uses for these elements."

Comment: The purpose of many of the <person> subelements is only understandable on the background of the use of TEI to record spoken corpora, e.g. <age>, <language>, <socecStatus>.

Suggestion: Change "three" to "four" and add:

"The fourth type is the person wishing to record information about persons who have served as informants in the creation of spoken corpora."

Comment: Since most TEI users, as far as I can make out, are using <person> for the second purpose listed (if not for the fifth mentioned below), the elements designed for use with spoken corpora can appear puzzling, since their aim is to capture information at a specific point in time, viz. when the interview was made, not to describe the life of a person as a whole.

Comment: <person> is also used to record information about persons who have participated in the creation of a TEI document. This use is noted at p. 436, bottom.

Suggestion: Change "four" to "five" and add:

"The fifth type is the person registering information relating to those who have taken part in the creation of a TEI document."

However, would also be happy with \(graphic|figure\) i.e. a choice between graphic or figure.  though I suppose that unecessarily complicates the content model. \(And then a use case would appear which wanted both graphic and figure inside char\).

Ok, I'd agree that retaining model.graphicLike but adding also figure here would be useful.

posts.text:
<figure> contains model.graphicLike, so adding it as an alternative would lead to an ambigiuous content model. 
Replacing model.graphLike with figure has the advantage of adding some other possibilities we might want here; the disadvantage of breaking existing documents which contain <graphic>s . But repairing the break is pretty trivial, and there are likely to be very few people affected \(other than James :-\(\) so on balance I am going to go with Council's clear wish to make the proposed change.

posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #98 graphic should allow desc child

posts.text:
This is precisely my use-case at the moment: I am converting from EpiDoc P4 to P5, and the P4 texts had the epigraphic photographs tagged as figures within a div\[@type=figure\]; each photograph had a URL and a caption \(figDesc\).

Since these photographs are \(in one way or another\) illustrations of the text, to which we might want to point from parts of the transcription, say, it seemed ideal to have these in <facsimile> rather than a typed div. But I don't see anywhere in facsimile that I can include a free-text description of the photograph. <surface> takes <desc>, so in theory I could have a surface for each image, containing both a graphic and a desc, but this smacks of abuse, since sometimes we have multiple photographs of the same face of the same piece of stone.

Allowing <desc> on <graphic> would certainly solve this problem, and I can't think of any other way to do so at the moment, so I support James's suggestion \(a\).

posts.text: Yes, if we are having model.glossLike on space and such, can we have it on graphic as well?

tickets.summary: table and table reference numbered differently
tickets.description:
== Summary ==

The XSLT2 stylesheet which produces LaTeX output may generate LaTeX output in which references to tables are not using the table numbers associated with the tables themselves.

== Versions ==

Ubuntu 10.4

I can reproduce the problem with this version:

$ dpkg-query -W tei-p5-xsl2
tei-p5-xsl2     5.30

And I can also reproduce it with the latest version of the trunk in SVN:

$ svn update
At revision 7733.

== How to Reproduce ==

1\. Download the attached zip file.

2\. Unzip.

3\. Edit the Makefile so that STYLE points to where your copy of the XSLT 2 version of the LaTeX stylesheet is.  \(To reproduce the bug for sure, you should use either one of the two versions I indicate above.\)

4\. Execute 

$ make test.pdf

== Actual Results ==

Go to page 3 of the resulting PDF. Notice how the table itself is labeled "Table 1.1" but the reference to the table at the top of the page says "Table 1".

== Expected Results ==

The number in the reference and the number in the table caption should be the same.

== Observations ==

It is not clear what the total set of conditions must be for this bug to happen but one condition is that the root <TEI> must have @rend = 'book'.

The problem is due to the processing code for <table> using \caption\{\} to generate the table number whereas the processing of <ptr> uses <xsl:number> to generate a number. In effect, LaTeX is responsible for assigning a number to the table but the XSL processor is responsible to assigning a number to the reference. Since LaTeX and the XSL processor do not necessarily have the same idea of numbering styles and counts, the numbers selected by the two may not be in step.

posts.text: files illustrating the problem
posts.author: lddubeau
posts.subject: #197 table and table reference numbered differently

posts.text: Another good call, thanks. Fixed in revision 7734 of XSLT 2.0 stylesheets, SFAICT.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #197 table and table reference numbered differently

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #197 table and table reference numbered differently

tickets.description:
p. 435

Text: "the degree of prescription"

Suggestion: "the degree of description"

posts.text:
Some background: this is in Manuscript Description, and the full para is:

"To cater for this diversity, here as elsewhere, these Guidelines
propose a flexible approach, in which encoders must choose for
themselves the degree of prescription appropriate to their needs, and
are provided with a choice of encoding mechanisms to support those
differing degrees."

In the context, I think "prescription" is intended to mean "the degree of constraint which the customized schema will impose on the encoder". If I'm right, then there's nothing wrong with it, although it might benefit from being expanded for clarity.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #550 prescription/description

posts.text:
I think both Martin's and Jens's interpretations of intent for this passage in the MS chapter are quite plausible at this point in the introduction to this chapter.  Perhaps we should actually expand it to address the degree of description and the degree of prescription?

It seems to me that this discussion of degrees is not at all specific to manuscript description and could apply to most any chapter, in which case it doesn't actually belong here but should instead be in "About these Guidelines" (chapter AB).
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #550 prescription/description

posts.text: I see. The passage occurs on both p. 301 and p. 435. Otherwise, "prescription" (or "prescribe") is not used in this "schematic" sense in the Guidelines. A more readily understandable word would surely be "restriction".
posts.author: jenspetersen
posts.subject: #550 prescription/description

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #550 prescription/description

posts.text: we have rephrased this to replace "degree of prescription" with "approach", to be more neutral, and cover both prescription and description.

tickets.description:
p. 440

Text: "Arne Magnusson"

Suggestion: "Arne Magnussen"

Comment: From tei-Bugs-3492947, I repeat:

"Arne Magnussen" is the danicised name form:
<http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Dansk_Biografisk_Leksikon/Uddannelse_og_undervisning/Professor/%C3%81rni_Magn%C3%BAsson>, <http://nfi.ku.dk/forskning/arnamagnaeansk/>.

It is the form used in the 1891 publication of his anonymous tract from 1699 on a Danish witch process: "Kort og sandfærdig Beretning om den vidtudraabte Besættelse udi Thisted til alles Efterretning af Original-Akter og troværdige Dokumenter uddragen og sammenskreven af Arne Magnussen …". 

In a Danish context, while "Arne Magnussen" would be the form he generally used himself, his use of the form "Arnas Magnussen" is also attested. In Icelandic, he would presumably have used the form "Arne Magnusson" (possibly "Arni Magnusson"), without accents. (Thanks to Guðvarður Már Gunnlaugsson for this information.)

The mixed form is also widely used in Denmark, as in "Arne Magnussons private Brevveksling" from 1920 and Hans Bekker-Nielsen and Ole Widding's biography "Arne Magnusson, den store håndskriftsamler, i 300-året for hans fødsel" from 1963 (the English translation 1972 uses the same form).

…

posts.text:
On the original ticket <https://sourceforge.net/p/tei/bugs/354/>, several issues were reported, of which this was one. Lou commented at one point:

"Re Arni Magnusson:

I have asked Matthew Driscoll to comment!"

Later the ticket was closed when everything else was dealt with; I would guess that either Lou got a response from Matthew that contradicted the bug report, or possibly no response came back and the issue got forgotten.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #560 Arne Magnusson, again

posts.text:

- **assigned_to**: Sebastian Rahtz

posts.text:
Have consulted Matthew Driscoll, who put the example in, and he reports
"Arne Magnusson...[is]... the form he used himself and the form generally used in publications about him published here, both in Danish and English". There does not seem to be a good reason to change this example.

tickets.description:
I started out noticing that the <valDesc>s of occurs= and withId= of <tagUsage> say “an integer number greater than zero” where the datatype \(very sensibly\) permits 0. I was just going to fix this by changing the <valDesc>s to “an integer number greater than or equal to zero”, when I noticed that the <remarks> of the ‘data.count’ tagdoc says “Only positive integer values are permitted” where the datatype clearly permits 0. Personally, it would never occur to me to limit a count to positive numbers — zero is a perfectly reasonable count. But I found myself wondering if TEI really wants to have ‘data.count’ exclude 0 as a possible value, as there are contexts where 0 makes no sense \(e.g., rows=, cols=, maxOccurs=\). I think the answer is “no”, although in some cases an extra restriction that the count cannot be 0 is appropriate. \(Or a different datatype\).

On further investigation I found at least one case where data.count is \(IMHO\) used inappropriately: group= of att.damaged. I am not sure why the grouping would be limited to numbers in the first place, but it is not a count in any case.

There are two cases where nonNegativeInteger is used directly, as opposed to via data.count, and I think these are both appropriate:
language/@usage
att.personal/@sort

The attributes defined as data.count are:
att.damaged/@group
att.tableDecoration/@rows
att.tableDecoration/@cols
att.transcriptional/@seq
tagUsage/@occurs
tagUsage/@withId
refState/@length
layout/@columns
layout/@ruledLines
layout/@writtenLines
handDesc/@hands
att.textCritical/@varSeq
age/@value
table/@rows
table/@cols
graph/@order
graph/@size
node/@inDegree
node/@outDegree
node/@degree
tree/@arity
tree/@order
root/@outDegree
iNode/@outDegree
datatype/@minOccurs
datatype/@maxOccurs

All tests against revision 6658.

posts.text: Is zero not a positive number? Anyway, I have changed the definition of data.count to make clearer that zero is permitted. In cases where zero is not appropriate, I think that should be expressed better by means of an rng:param as in the case of language/@usage , or as an additional constraint. I don't understand why you think data.count is inappropriate for att.perrsonal/@sort so I've left that alone for now.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #105 data.count woes

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #105 data.count woes

tickets.description:
The value description of absolute= of <when> says “Times may be given
in standard form, as specified in the Encoding Declarations section of
the header.”. But

a\) there is no “Encoding Declarations section” of the TEI header
\(unless this is a deliberately obscure way to refer to the encoding
description :-\),

b\) if there were it shouldn't be capitalized, 

c\) if one were to record a standard form for a time, it would be nice
to have more advice than just in the encoding description,

and, most importantly,

d\) the datatype is data.temporal.w3c, which is a particular standard
form, so nothing need be recorded anyway.

I think the entire <valDesc> should just be deleted. The <remarks> are
also somewhat confusing, as origin= of <timeline> is a pointer to a
<when> \(or another <timeline>\), not an element. It may also be useful
to discuss how to express an absolute= that is precise to the hour or
minute, since the datatype does not permit expressing this.

posts.text: I agree that the valDesc is otiose and have removed it. Also reworded the remarks to be a bit clearer at v 6671

tickets.summary: <remarks> of origin= of <timeline> confusing at best
tickets.description: The <remarks> section in the definition of the origin= attribute of the <timeline> element are at best confusing, at worst nonsense. It says “If the absolute value for the time of origin is not known, an arbitrary time \(such as 00:00\) should be used.”. Used where? On this attribute? Its datatype is data.pointer — putting “00:00” on the value of origin= of <timeline> suggests that the origin time is found as the root element of a file named “00:00” in the same directory as the current file \(whose root had better be a <when>, I guess\). As the absolute= of the <when> to which this <origin> points? If so, the datatype of absolute= of <when> is data.temporal.w3c, so “00:00” is not a valid value, and would mean midnight in any case.

posts.text: While I agree the suggestion in the text is pretty weird, it's less clear what one should do in the \(not uncommon\) case where the origin is unknown, and all the other timings are relative to it. What would you suggest?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #108 <remarks> of origin= of <timeline> confusing at best

Off the top of my head one thought is to change the definition of absolute= of <when> to
attribute absolute \{ data.temporal.w3c | "origin" \}
with the additional constraint that only 1 <when> child of any given <timeline> may have absolute="origin".
Then just leave origin= of <timeline> as a pointer that always points to a <when> child.

posts.text: Wouldn't it be simpler just to say that @origin is not required, and that if it is not supplied, the implication is that the origin of the timeline is unknown? The various <when> elements it contains can still be defined relative to one another,

posts.text: Uhh ... yes, that is definitely simpler, and I think it would be sufficient. That is, off the top of my head I haven't come up with any cases that could not be covered. So I like it.

posts.text: OK, I've made @origin optional and added a sentemce explaining what that means, as of revision 6703

tickets.summary: NOT making changes actually CAUSES changes in customization
tickets.description:
Relevant version string:

"This is Roma version 3.12, last updated 2009-07-13. Using TEI P5 version 1.4.1. Last updated on July 1st 2009."

\(Note that the bug was also happening on the version of Roma released just before this one.  Travel prevented me from releasing the bug report before the new version was released.\)


Introduction
============

This is a complicated bug.  I'm going to provide a summary.  However, the steps to reproduce the bug are many so I've made a desktop recording which I'm hosting here:

http://lddubeau.com/downloads/tei-bug-20090720.ogv

I would have attached the recording to this bug report but SourceForge does not accept large attachments.


Summary
=======

Basically, it appears that just navigating the GUI \*without requesting changes\* causes Roma to still make some changes to the customization behind the scenes.  In the following description, the user creates an initial schema and then inspects elements and attributes without requesting changes.  In the following description, all the saved files are attached to this bug report in a zip file called myTEI.zip

1\. The user creates a customization from a minimal schema.  He adds the "test" element and adds to this element the "test1" attribute.  He saves the rnc as myTEI-1.rnc and the customization as myTEI-1.xml.  Up to this point everything is normal.

2\. The user then goes back to check on the "test" element and clicks "Save" WITHOUT actually making any changes.  When he returns to the "Schema" tab, he is greeted with the following error message:


Your schema is not valid\!\!

DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Did not expect element classes there
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Element elementSpec has extra content: classes
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Element moduleRef has wrong namespace: expecting http://www.ascc.net/xml/schematron
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Element schemaSpec has extra content: moduleRef
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Element TEI failed to validate content

He saves the rnc as myTEI-2.rnc and the customization as myTEI-2.xml.  Note here that, upon cursory inspection, myTEI-2.rnc seems to be valid.

3\. The user then goes back to check on the "test1" attribute of the "test" element.  When presented with the list of attributes, he clicks "Save" WITHOUT actually making any changes.  When he returns to the "Schema" tab, the error message remains the same. He saves the rnc as myTEI-3.rnc and the customization as myTEI-3.xml.


Observations
============

1\. It appears that the difference between myTEI-1.xml and myTEI-2.xml is the location of the <attList> element.  This is clearly visible when using ediff to compare the two files.

2\. It appears that the difference between myTEI-2.xml and myTEI-3.xml is that the "mode" attribute on the definition of the "test1" attribute goes from "add" to "change".  Again, ediff shows this clearly.

3\. There is no significant difference between myTEI-1.rnc and myTEI-2.rnc.  \(Only a timestamp changes.\)

4\. myTEI-3.rnc differs from the two other rnc files in that the "test1" attribute is missing.  This is probably related to observation 2 above.

5\. Going to the "Sanity Checker" tab to check the schema does not result in any significant error message.  The checker always say "Schema is CORRECT\!", no matter whether it is checking myTEI-1.rnc, myTEI-2.rnc or myTEI-3.rnc.

tickets.description: It appears that <meeting> is not allowed as a child of <titleStmt>. What if you encode conference proceedings as a born-digital TEI document? There's no place to record the meeting name\!

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #133 meeting as child of <titleStmt>

posts.text:
It looks like the history of this is as follows:

In P4, <meeting> was allowed only as a child of <monogr>, for use in a formal bibliographic structure.

During P5 development, at rev 3634, 2007-10-15, Lou B committed the change that "classified" <meeting>, adding it to model.divWrapper and model.biblPart. The guidelines text was changed at the same time to read, "contains the formalized descriptive title for a meeting or conference, for use in a bibliographic description for an item derived from such a meeting, or as a heading or preamble to publications emanating from it." The intent was clearly to permit more general use of <meeting>, within an unstructured <bibl> or at the head of a division.

So... the expectation that it might be allowed within <titleStmt> seems legitimate. There are two ways to accomplish this:

1\. by adding it explicitly;

2\. by adding it to model.respLike \(moving it there from model.biblPart, really\)

The negative to \#1 is mainly that this would be an ad hoc addition to titleStmt \(and why not allow in that case various other elements?\)

The negative to \#2 is that all elements now in model.respLike are more or less "personal" \(author editor funder principal respStmt sponsor\). On the other hand, a funder or sponsor can be corporate entities, with statuses not too different from that of a "meeting". Also, elements in model.respLike are used by model.msItemPart; <meeting> doesn't make a lot of sense in that context.

DS suggests that \#2 is a marginally better option, to avoid the single ad hoc addition of <meeting> to <titleStmt>.
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #133 meeting as child of <titleStmt>

posts.text:
Actually, on further thought I believe there is a simple choice: say "yes" or "no" to adding <meeting> to model.respLike. The Guidlines say this about the elements in model.respLike that can occur in <titleStmt>:

"The elements author, editor, sponsor, funder, and principal, are specializations of the more general respStmt element. These elements are used to provide the statements of responsibility which identify the person\(s\) responsible for the intellectual or artistic content of an item and any corporate bodies from which it emanates."

Does "meeting" belong to that group, or not?
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #133 meeting as child of <titleStmt>

posts.text: I agree with David that we should just add <meeting> to model.respLike
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #133 meeting as child of <titleStmt>

posts.text: At revisions 7106 <meeting>  added to model.respLike \( and removed from model.biblPart to avoid duplicate definition\)
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #133 meeting as child of <titleStmt>

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed

This suggests that <witDetail> can occur inline without a @target attribute, while the schema definition \(http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-witDetail.html\) specifies @target as a mandatory attribute.

tickets.description:
In proofreading a DH proposal for a colleague this morning I've read through Guidelines section 7.2.2 \(http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/DR.html\#DRSP\) and found what I believe are errors \(or issues\) simply because the language is out of date. Specifically, the existing text refers to IDREFS and doesn't take into account the existence of the namesdates module.

Currently:

"The value of the @who attribute however is a unique code, probably made up by the transcriber, which will unambiguously identify the character to whom the speech is assigned. To enforce this uniqueness, the base tag set for drama defines the value of this attribute as IDREFS. This means that the codes included in it must correspond with codes which are specified elsewhere in the document as identifiers for particular elements, typically the role element in the cast list where the character is named or described, as discussed in 7.1 Front and Back Matter  above."

Perhaps it could be rewritten something like this: 

"The value of the @who attribute however serves to unambiguously identify the character to whom the speech is assigned. Having the datatype data.pointer, @who may point to a person element in the TEI header \(http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CC.html\#CCAHPA\), to a role element in the cast list \(http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/DR.html\#DRCAST\), or to any external source that may be referenced via a URI." 

I realize this is following the "hunt and peck" approach to Guidelines development, but unless there is a strong feeling that the entire chapter should be re-evaluated I hope we can agree to make this relatively minor but nevertheless important change. I've also added this as a feature request.

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #136 Minor issues with 7.2.2 (Speeches and Speakers)

posts.text:
Well spotted\! At rev 7036,  I have reworded the para as follows:

The
<att>who</att> attribute however contains one or more pointer values,
each of which indicates one or more other XML elements documenting the
character to whom the speech is assigned.  Typically, this attribute
might point to a <gi>person</gi> element in the TEI header <ptr
target="\#CCAHPA"/>, to a <gi>role</gi> element in the cast list <ptr
target="\#DRCAST"/>, or even to some external source such as an online
handbook of dramatic roles. The most usual case is that the pointer
value supplied \(prefixed by a sharp sign\) corresponds with the value  of an <att>xml:id</att> attribute
used  elsewhere in the document to
identify a particular element, as in the following examples:
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #136 Minor issues with 7.2.2 (Speeches and Speakers)

posts.text: I also just checked -- there are now only two other occurrences of the string  "IDREF" in the text of the Guidelines, both in TD, where they probably belong.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #136 Minor issues with 7.2.2 (Speeches and Speakers)

tickets.description:
In the "Add a new attribute" page:

\* With respect to the "Closed list?" radio buttons, it seems impossible to change the value from "yes" to "no".
\* When there is a list of possible attribute values in the "List of values" input box, if the input box is cleared of its contents and the form submitted, the values in the list remain unchanged and are not deleted as expected.
\* Atttributes entered in the "List of values" input box, delimited by commas, are not trimmed to remove surrounding whitespace.  e.g., entering "valueOne, valueTwo, valueThree" will produce attribute values "valueOne", " valueTwo", " valueThree".

Additionally, with, e.g., the element <add>, this element should inherit \(in tei\_all.rng\) some attribute classes such as att.editLike and att.responsibility, but these don't show up.

Furthermore, adding pointer-type attribute values in the "List of values" such as "\#handOne", "\#handTwo", etc., produces the following schema errors:

Your schema is not valid\!\!
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Type Name doesn't allow value '\#handOne'
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Element valItem failed to validate attributes
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Type Name doesn't allow value '\#handTwo'
DOMDocument::relaxNGValidate\(\) \[function.DOMDocument-relaxNGValidate\]: Element valItem failed to validate attributes

I am also seeing illegal character errors in OxygenXML when generating a schema, where \(it seems\) documentation text is being placed inside <define/>, whilst a copy of this text is also being placed \(correctly, I presume\) inside the <a:documentation/> element.

I'm also having trouble editing text inside some HTML <textarea> elements of the Roma web-interface, in particular on the "Customize" page it seems necessary to first delete all the text, submit the form and then type your new text, otherwise it simply appends the replaced text to the end of the default text.  Additionally, on the "Defining a new element" page, the "Description" <textarea> doesn't seem to apply changes when the form is submitted.

posts.text:
I'll start looking at these. Some may be easy to solve.

Can you give a test for how to reproduce "I am also seeing illegal character errors in OxygenXML when generating a schema, where \(it seems\) documentation text is being placed inside <define/>"?
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

posts.text: I am also noticing \(again on the "Add a new attribute" page\) that if one types in a few values for the attribute and makes it a closed list, the produced schema does not enforce that closed list.  However, if one makes it a required attribute, the closed list of values is enforced in the schema.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

posts.text:
I believe the schema errors \(produced when defining a list of possible values for a given attribute\) are not a Roma bug, but rather stem from the definition of @ident in <valItem>, which is currently a member of the attribute class att.identified.  This inappropriately limits the value to the datatype data.name \(= an XML name\), but many attributes use other datatypes which are not so restrictive \(e.g., data.pointer in the example given above\) and these all produce schema errors.

The solution is, I suppose, to submit this as a TEI bug, requesting a change to <valItem> to allow @ident to accept CDATA, possibly involving a rename of @ident itself.  This is a bit beyond my level of knowledge of XML/TEI, and I'm not sure of the protocol here, but I'll submit this as a bug if you agree.
posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

posts.text:
A few more points to note...

At present, attribute classes are still listed even if their parent module has been deleted.

It would be nice to have the ability to remove entire attribute classes.

It would also be good to be able to remove an element's membership of an entire attribute class.  ODD files imported into Roma which use this method aren't processed properly.

It would be nice if attributes could be listed by inheritance rather than seemingly in random order on the per-element "List of attributes" page.

In "Change Classes"->"changeAttributes", there is no title, but where it should be it just has "List of attributes: " without printing the class name.
posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

posts.text: I have not been able to look at this yet, so I am marking it as being at risk

posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

posts.subject: #137 "Add new attribute" errors, etc.

tickets.description: Shouldn't the data type of @scribe and @script be data.pointer rather than data.name? I would expect an explanation \(i.e. biographical details about the scribe, or characteristics of the script\) somewhere else if these attributes are filled. Thus, the value of the attribute would be a pointer instead of just a name of something? Especially as the description of @scribe states, that it "gives a standard name or other identifier" \(\!\).

posts.text: I can see why you might want this for @scribe, assuming you know more about the scribe than their conventional name \(though how often is that the case?\), but what element would @script point to? For most usages these attributes are  just a convenient way of normalising references  \(like @key\) rather than requiring the stricter kind of validation which @ref or your proposal would permit-- or rather, require. This change would thus break a lot of existing documents.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text:
I agree Torsten you but I also see Lou's point about retro-compatibility. Perhaps we should add @scriptRef as pointer \(as we did for <w> which has now @lemma and @lemmaRef for this very reason\) and leave @script as it is. We definitely need a way to describe scripts properly\! 
Once we have done it, I think we have also to add something similar to <handNotes> in the <profileDesc> in order to describe a script properly.
posts.author: epierazzo
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text: Presumably if @scribe \(or @scribeRef\) is a pointer it should point to a <person> and @script or @scriptRef should point to a <handNote>?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text:
No to <handNote>, which describe the type of hand, but to something like <scriptNote> that describe the kind of script. For instance you want to say that the type of script is used mainly for the production of books or for charters; that was used mostly in a particular area/scriptorium, and in a particular date range. You can also say that the script is characterised by a particular shape of a given letter etc.
Into a <handNote> you will perhaps say that this particular scribe uses the script in a personal way, with log-short descendant, using a pen which is cut in a different way, using an ink of a given colour, etc.
Make sense?
posts.author: epierazzo
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text: Nowhere to define a script; need to point to scribe and to script, both distinct. Not the same as hand. Need to decide on referring policy.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text: the new <scriptNote>/<scriptDesc> should be considered parallel to <typeNote>/<typeDesc> \(http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-typeDesc.html and http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-typeNote.html\)
posts.author: dot_porter
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text:
Proposal is \(I think\): 1. define new <scriptDesc> containing multiple <scriptNote>s \(analagous to typeNote for typography\)
2\. Make @script a data pointer, pointing to a <scriptNote>
3\. Make @scribe a data pointer, pointing to a <person> somewhere

The problem with \(2\) is that this is quite a lot of overhead if all you want to say is @script="fraktur" and also breaks existing documents. Hence

4\. Leave @script and @scribe unchanged, but add @scriptRef and @scribeRef explicitly as pointing variants on them

Do we need both <typeNote> and <scriptNote>? would it not be better to define <writingNote> for either?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text: Adding @scriptRef and @scribeRef as pointers is uncontroversial and does not break backward compatibility, so I'd agree with that. Any other changes need more discussion.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text:
To clarify, the proposal we are considering is to do both of the following:

a\) define new <scriptDesc> containing multiple
<scriptNote>s \(analagous to typeNote for typography\)

b\) Leave @script and @scribe unchanged, but add @scriptRef and @scribeRef
explicitly as pointing variants on these elements.  These new attributes would be available in every place that @script and @scribe are currently available, respectively.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text:
I agree with the addition of @scriptRef & @scribeRef.

I wonder though about the need for a new scriptNote etc. if there is already @typeNote which serves almost exactly the same function. We have often agreed to use elements named <ms\*> to describe something that isn't technically a "manuscript", so why not use typeNote \(or rename it <writingNote> as Lou suggests\) to include script information?
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.text: Added scriptNote and scriptDesc, @scribeRef and @scriptRef. Also added some wording to PH and MS to explain how they are to be used. Need some examples and test files. Note also that we have both <handDesc> within <physDesc> and <handNotes> within <profileDesc> to contain <handNote> elements; this seems like overkill.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

posts.subject: #138 data type of @scribe and @script

tickets.description: <label> appears to me to have an overly restrictive content model. For instance, it will not allow <bibl>. Different types of lists might often include in <label> elements an author/title, which could/should be wrapped in a <bibl>. Also, <soCalled> is allowed, but <q> is not. This seems wrong too. I'm using an odd, generated by the most recent version of Roma \(as of today's date\) using the more recent version of P5 \(as of today's date\).

posts.text: <label> is defined as containing macro.phraseSeq, as are most other phrase level elements. <q> and <bibl> are "inter" level which is why they're not permitted here. Can you show us some real examples in which you'd want to put a <bibl> into a <label> ? It seems unlikely to me.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text:
Here is my use case needing <bibl> inside of <label>. I have a chronology of an author's life, represented as a table. Every row in the first column is a year of the author's life. Each cell of the second column contains a gloss list \(e.g., \(<label>,<item>\)+\) of events for the corresponding year author's life. In the gloss list the <label> is a short label for the event, the <item> is a gloss with further detail about the event. Some of the events in the author's life are the publications of his works. So some <label>s contain <title>s. If I just needed titles I could get by without the <bibl>.  But I have a third column, which provides the literary context for the author's life and includes the publication of major works by other authors, so there I have <author> and <title> in a <label>.  And where more than one related bibliographic element appears in a text, my preference is to wrap them in a <bibl> to make the relationship explicit. A fourth column includes the historical and cultural context for the author's life, and so some <label>s there include titles of paintings \(<title>\) and artists \(<respStmt>\), which I also would prefer to wrap in a <bibl>.

And can we agree that where <soCalled> is allowed, <q type="soCalled"> should also be allowed? :-\)
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text: I forgot to log in when commenting. The comment from "nobody" \(a real boost to my self-esteem\) on 2010-01-15 15:52 is from me, the original poster of the issue.
posts.author: johnwalsh
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text:
So this raises two issues:
1\) Why is model.qLike a member of model.inter? At first glance, seems silly to me. model.quoteLike, yes, but qLike?
2\) Why wouldn't members of model.inter be allowed in <label>? The members of model.inter are those things that are allowed inside paragraphs \(as well as elsewhere\) — shouldn't stuff that can go in a paragraph be able to go in a label inside said paragraph? \(In truth, I'm hard pressed to come up with a reason to have a <table> in a <label>, but I'm asking in the big picture such that a singe counter-example doesn't really address the issue satisfactorily.\)
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text:
I think this is a misuse of <label> It's really just meant to contain a short phrase or, um, label for an item in glossary lists, which are very simple cases of tables \(as it says somewhere\). Surely, if  you have a four column table, wouldn't it be better to encode it as a table, rather than trying to squash it into a list? Or have I misunderstood the use case?

To answer Syd's questions: qLike is in model inter for compatibility with quoteLike, since the two are structurally \(if not semantically\) identical. And model inter isn't allowed in phrase-level elements because only some of its members can appear there.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text:
Lou, 

Indeed the data is encoded as a four-column table.  The first column contains dates—one year in each cell. Every cell of the second, third, and fourth columns contains a gloss list of events that occur in that year. Sometimes an "event" is the publication of a text, which is why I was wanting <bibl> in <label>.

John
posts.author: johnwalsh
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text:
In response to Lou’s reply …

I am not sure in what respect model.qLike and model.quoteLike are structurally similar. Indeed, I thought they were separate classes precisely because they are semantically different. model.quoteLike contains only things that go inside or between paras \(<quote>, <cit>\), whereas model.qLike also contains things that \(IMHO\) should not go between paras \(<q>, <said>\).

I don’t think model.qLike should be a member of model.inter — I think it is model.quoteLike that should be a member of model.inter.

As for John's problematic table with gloss-lists inside that have bibls-in-label, I'm not sure what to do. Personally, I'm not very fond of the label-item pairs model of a list, and might be inclined to encode something like this using <label> or <bibl> as the first child of <item>. That said, I'm not sure there's a really good reason \*not\* to have <bibl> in <label>. And certainly <q> should be allowed in <label>, since <hi> is. Just my 2¢.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text: Council sees no need to change content model of <label> at this time.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #146 Restrictive content model of label

posts.text:
Hear, hear\! Indeed. As a way to enumerate the possible values of an attribute, ident= of <valItem> clearly results in TEI ODD being broken as designed. E.g., one might want to enumerate the various symbols used to indicate angles: U+00B0, U+2032, U+2033; or the common ways of representing dimensionality: 1D, 2D, 3D; or the books of the bible: 1 Kings, 2 Corinthians; or arithmetic operators: +, -, ÷, ×; etc.

I have been complaining about this problem since at least late 2005. However, given that P5 has been published since 2007, and \(to my knowledge\) no one else has ever complained until today, it will not surprise me if there is insufficient community interest in fixing this obvious flaw for the Consortium to actually do so.

\(BTW, just re-defining valItem/@ident to be rng:text instead of xsd:Name is probably not a good solution — besides the inconsistency with other uses if ident=, it could conceivably throw a monkey-wrench into processing. Remember that individual <valItem>s actually need to be identifiable so they can have <altIdent>s or be changed or deleted by a subsequent <valItem mode="change|delete">. Probably better to provide for zero or more child <val> elements \(ostensibly with different values of xml:lang=\), and agree that if there is no child <val>, then use the ident= as the enumerated value.\)
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #148 @ident data type problem with <valItem>

posts.text:
I see what you mean about potential problems if valItem/@ident becomes a string, but these aren't IDs and no elements or attributes are actually being created, so I rather doubt it would be necessary to use a more complex solution, like a valItem/val or even valItem/text\(\) \(as per <altIdent>\).

At the moment, using non-XML Names in valItem/@ident doesn't seem to cause fatal errors when compiling a schema using Roma, though the PHP DOMDocument extension does complain a bit \(which is how I noticed the problem\).  Perhaps if it did cause a fatal error in someone's ODD processor, there might be more interest in resolving the issue\!
posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #148 @ident data type problem with <valItem>

posts.text: Many many things would break  if we went back on the design decision that @ident should have a datatype of data.name. As such this proposal fails the Birnbaum doctrine and I cannot see any overriding advantage in permitting @ident to be anything other than a data.name. There is however a reasonable requirement to specify a closed set of values in a valList the individual members of which are \*not\* necessarily names and we should think of some way of doing that in the proposed revision of ODD. Suggestions welcomed.

posts.subject: #148 @ident data type problem with <valItem>

posts.text: I feel I'm rather out of my depth on this one, but I think Syd's suggestion of using <val> would work.  valItem/@ident could perhaps still be specified by the user for backwards compatibility, but applications should prefer the <val> when present.

posts.text:
This example is nonsensical. What does it mean? can I say <measure commodity="HR"> or <measure commodity="pulse rate">  or only one depending on some other parameter or what?

You seem to be forgetting that the semantics defined for @ident in this context is to supply a \(language-independent\) value for an attribute. If what you want is to supply language specific glosses for the value used, use <gloss>, possibly within the \(language-specific\) desc.

posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #148 @ident data type problem with <valItem>

posts.text: Council reviewed the original proposal, and agreed \(eventually\) that  @ident on vaIIem to be should be locally defined with a  more flexible datatype  \(string was proposed\) . This entails removing it from the att.identifiable class, of course, and hence either locally defining @mode., which is also inherited from that class,  or defining a new class from which @mode can be inherited.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #148 @ident data type problem with <valItem>

posts.text:
Jolly good.

Re: @mode, there are currently 7 elements each with their own locally defined @mode.  Of those, only <valItem> and <valDesc> use the same enumerated values \(add \[default\], delete, change, replace\), the others being <alt>, <altGrp>, <channel>, <classes> and <memberOf>.

If @mode were became its own class \(with the add/delete/change/replace values\) it would therefore be able to absorb the current members of att.identified and also the three <val...> elements, but not the others.  All other things being equal, this option seems slightly less messy from a structural perspective than increasing the already fairly long list of elements each with their own @mode, however it would seem to involve rather more disruption than is actually necessary to achieve the same thing, so I would suggest just going with a locally defined @mode.

<valItem> currently inherits @predeclare and @module from att.identified, but the element doesn't actually seem to need them, so I suppose <valItem> just needs @ident and @mode.

posts.subject: #148 @ident data type problem with <valItem>

At rev 7183: Explicitly define @mode and @ident on valItem; remove it from att.identified; 
allow rng:text as datatype for @ident.
