tickets.description: TEI/@version is an xsd:decimal, but TEI version numbers aren't decimals, e.g. "1.5.0".  Can I suggest changing this to something more applicable, perhaps data.enumerated.  This would allow a limited range of values, and could even be reduced to one \(the current value\), thus causing a validation error if one attempts to validate against the wrong TEI schema version.

posts.text:
- **labels**:  --> TEI: Definition of Elements/Attributes/Classes
- **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text:
When defined, this attribute was for the base version of the Guidelines as a whole \(e.g. P5 as opposed to P4\), and we had not yet set in place the programme of regular version releases.  It would certainly make sense for this now to be used for point release numbers e.g.  5.1.2 

Your suggestion of making it data.enumerated is a good one, since it would permit projects to define explicitly the versions for which a given document is valid in their project ODD. Let's see what the Council thinks...
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text: I've just noticed that this also needs to be altered for <unicodeName>, since the Unicode Consortium also use a non-numeric versioning system.  Also it applies to <teiCorpus>.
posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text:
"Version numbers for the Unicode Standard consist of three fields, denoting the major version, the minor version, and the update version, respectively. For example, “Unicode 3.1.1” indicates major version 3 of the Unicode Standard, minor version 1 of Unicode 3, and update version 1 of minor version Unicode 3.1." it says here \(http://unicode.org/versions/\#Version\_Numbering\). So the current definition for <unicodeName> \(data.numeric\) is indeed wrong, but wrong in a slight different way from the definition for TEI/@version or teiCorpus/@version

I'm now wondering whether we shouldnt define a "data.version" datatype -- a pattern which matches the Unicode spec above -- rather than use data.enumerated
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text:
That wouldn't work for TEI v5.1.4.1 though.  \`\[0-9\]+\(\\.\[0-9\]+\)\{2,3\}\` would cover it, but then one could imagine circumstances in future where it might be desirable to use @version for more idiosyncratic version numbers -- which is presumably why @version in att.translatable is a data.word.

I still like the idea of data.enumerated for TEI/@version being useful as a sanity check in official releases, so that \(e.g.\) if someone is using the TEI templates in oXygen XML and then updates oXygen without realising they're updating TEI with it, the first schema error they'll see will \(probably\) be TEI/@version.

It would also be useful for projects to have TEI/@version as data.enumerated so that conformance \(or lack of\) could be specified in an ODD, or simply as a sanity check, e.g. @version="ManuscriptProjectVersion2".
posts.author: ianrons
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text: @version in att.translatable should actually be a date, but I take the point. The trouble with making @version use an enumerated list is that we then have to update that list for every new version. This might be bearable if it were automated I suppose. Of course it remains possible for people to customize the accepable values for @version in their ODD.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text: Agreed to make datatype conform to our practice
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text:
A @version attribute exists on each of the elements <application>,
<teiCorpus>, <TEI> and <unicodeName>. A similarly named attribute is
also supplied by the class att.translatable, members of which are
desc, exemplum, gloss, remarks, and valDesc. The datatypes specified
for this attribute vary, as follows:

1\. On att.translatable it's data.word and there is a note saying "The
version may be a number, a letter or a date"

2\. On <application> it's a token matching a specific RNG pattern
\[\d\]+\[a-z\]\*\[\d\]\*\(\\.\[\d\]+\[a-z\]\*\[\d\]\*\)\{0,3\}

3\. On <TEI> and <teiCorpus> it's explicitly a W3C decimal number.

4\. On unicodeName its the TEI-defined data.numeric \(which matches all
sorts of things\)

Obviously the datatypes for @version on TEI, teiCorpus, and
unicodeName are just plain wrong \(the first two don't match our actual
current practice, and the last doesn't match the Unicode
requirement\). In an ideal world, we'd like attributes with the same
name to have the same datatype, so one solution would be to give
everything the same datatype as <application>. Unfortunately the
pattern defined there is too permissive for either Unicodename or TEI
version \(neither permits letters or a 4th number\), so I have for the
moment defined a new datatype data.version which matches the Unicode spec, and propose we restrict ourselves to that.

There remains the problem of the @version provided by in the
att.translatable class, which is uniformly a date, with hyphens
separating the parts. We could at a pinch make that conform to the
same pattern by permitting hyphens as well as dots in the pattern, but
that I think that would be cheating. We could consider renaming the
@version you get from att.translatable to "translateDate" or some
such; so far as I know the attribute is only used for internal ODD
processing by the TEI so the compatibility issue is less severe. Note
that the semantics of this @version are quite different from the
others -- it carries the date when an ODD component was last
\*translated\* which is usually quite different from when the ODD
component itself was last modified, and nothing to do with the version
number of the P5 release into which that component was eventually
incorporated.

There is an outstanding issue about how the @version on these
translateable elements should be used in our workflow specifically how we ensure consistency when the English language version has changed and
the translations have not.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text:
Lou's latest comment raised some outstanding questions, and for the record, it's not clear how they were resolved.  So for historians, I note the following:

1\. On att.translatable, @version has been renamed to @versionDate per bug 3393781.

3\. TEI@version now refers to the TEI's major release number \("P"\) per bug 3393781.  So the original issue raised in the bug was thus resolved.

4\. On <unicodeName> it's now data.version.

The problem that "remains" has been resolved by creation of @versionDate.

The "outstanding issue" was resolved by adding instructions on use of @versionDate to tcw22 in June 2012.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

posts.text: - **status**: closed --> closed-fixed
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #150 TEI/@version

tickets.description:
In MS. description, use of <dimensions> is only practical if all the leaves in the manuscript are the same size.  Whilst this is often the case, there are many cases \(for instance, collections of correspondence\) where leaves are of differing sizes.  It would be helpful if @from, @to and @scheme \(as per <locus>\) could be added in order to accomplish this.

Here is an example of a real-world case:
Folios 1-13 measure 315-320mm high by 205mm wide and fol. 14 measures 220mm by 205mm. All other leaves measure 295-300mm by 205mm with the following exceptions: fol. 15 \(175mm x 140mm\), fol. 46 \(77mm x 252mm\), fol. 81 \(200m x 142mm\), fol. 87 \(134mm x 190mm\), fol. 97 \(112mm x 123mm\), fol. 99 \(70mm x 127mm\), and fols. 141-169 \(188mm x 150mm\).

tickets.description: The current legal values for title/@level do not fully encompass the range of possibilities, in particular it isn't really possible to refer to an item by its catalogue entry.  @level="u" comes close, but that is intended for unpublished dissertations and would be doing double time.  It would be better to have something like @level="c" to specify a catalogue entry, e.g. <title level="c">Corpus Christi MS. 251</title>.

posts.text:
I am not quite sure what you mean by a "catalogue entry" here: the example suggests you are thinking of an identifier such as a catalogue number which would not be considered to be a title of any sort. The concept of bibliographic level is one we've inherited from ISBD, and it relates very specifically to a title  -- does the title apply to a "monograph" or to an "analytic" or "serial". A catalogue number is probably best recorded using the <idno> element, or \(if that's the title you want to give a work\) then it's probably a monographic title. 

@level is not to be confused with @type... you could use the latter to say that this title is derived from a catalogue number of course.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #152 title/@level not fully comprehensive

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #152 title/@level not fully comprehensive

tickets.description:
1\. It seems potentially misleading that after characterizing pointers as pointer elements \(<ptr/> and friends\), the chapter uses the term "pointer" when defining the TEI XPointer schemes. Because those "pointer" arguments are to be treated as resource identifiers, perhaps the best fix could be to replace e.g. range\(pointer, pointer\) with something ugly like range\(res-ident, res-ident\).

2\. There is a mistake in 16.9.5: "the expression range\(/1/2/1.0,/1/2/11.1\) will select the whole poem" should be "the expression range\(element\(/1/2/1.0\),element\(/1/2/11.1\)\) will select the whole poem"

3\. Next, consider fn. 52 and 53:

52: "bare names \(i.e. values of xml:id references\) "
53: "Bare names \(i.e., xml:id  values\)"

I might try to interpret 52 as assuming that a reference to an xml:id \(e.g. '\#a'\) has the value 'a', but why complicate the matters and terms. Say "xml:id values" in both cases instead.

4\. Another thing is that, as far as I know, the term "bare name" \(or maybe even "barename"\) is deprecated and replaced with "shorthand pointer". But perhaps that shouldn't influence the text of the Guidelines, because "bare name" is much more intuitive. Still, a footnote might be in order, and the normative reference here is the xptr-framework document \(http://www.w3.org/TR/xptr-framework/\).

posts.text:
Oops, by "resource identifiers" I meant fragment identifiers. 

Hence range\(fragm-ident, fragm-ident\) or something similar -- somewhat ugly but mnemonic, and that is important \(why make the reader search for the definition of the argument in the text if you can supply a hint already within the  'prototype' of the given scheme\).

tickets.description:
0\) The hand= attribute of att.transcriptional is declared as data.pointer, but the new= attribute of <handShift>, which seems to perform exactly the same function, is declared as data.code. Since both of these datatypes boil down to xsd:anyURI, there is no formal constraint difference, but nonetheless, they should match.

1\) The prose in the <valDesc> of hand= of att.transcriptional that constrains it to point to a single <handNote> is clearer and more precise than that of the <valDesc> of new= of <handShift>.

2\) An encoder should be able to easily express that either hand A or hand B wrote the passage, not sure which, and the Guidelines should have an example of how to do this. One reasonable mechanism would be to allow these attributes to point to an <alt>.

Cf: http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1001&L=TEI-MS-SIG&T=0&F=&S=&P=631
and: http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1001&L=TEI-MS-SIG&T=0&F=&S=&P=726

posts.text:
This is a consequence of the decision to map data.code onto xsd:anyURI rather than to xsd:string \(like data.key\) . Irrespective of the mapping, usage and lots of text in the Guidelines alike expect data.code to map to something which is not necessarily a pointer, and not necessarily one of an enumeration.

The reason for having both @hand and <handShift/> is I hope self-evident; it would be better if they both permitted something like a @ref and something like @key I guess.

The requirement to say "it's either hand A or hand B" is discussed also in the  genetic editions proposal, which suggests a couple of ways of doing it.

posts.text: Roma uses stylesheets which contain a small number of TEI-specific features to cope with the way the P5 source is organized, one of which is the need to select examples for output by xml:lang.  It's possible that the rules for inheritance of xml:lang values are not being properly processed by the stylesheets, however, since in the P5 context they would never be of any use \(because every exemplum has siblings in several languages\). The namespace issue is different however, and should probably be in a separate ticket.

posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #159 Marking centuries in @when

posts.text: This is exactly what had worried me with the fact of having two such sets of attributes. Maybe we should work towards convergence: Deprecating the iso set and making the other one more flexible.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #159 Marking centuries in @when

posts.text: I don't think that's a viable option. We propose these attributes as ways of normalizing date and time values. It's our bad luck that there are two different existing normalisations for such things, one sponsored by ISO, and the other by W3C. Are you seriously proposing that the TEI should invent a third set of normalizations, neither one nor the other? That might make sense if it supported an intersection of the two, but not if it was a superset. When we looked at this before, we concluded that we just had to live with both, and force people to be explicit about which they are using. Hence the uncomfortable existence of the two sets of attributes. It might, I suppose, be argued that instead of mapping \(eg\) @when to @when-w3c, we should support only @when-w3c, but that seems like needlessly cruelty.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #159 Marking centuries in @when

posts.text: I am closing this, since there is a way of doing what the original request asks for.

tickets.description:
1\) The Guidelines are inconsistent in use of "TEI Abstract Model" and "TEI abstract model".

2\) The last paragraph of §23.3.3.1 does not seem to specify that the semantics of the elements must correspond to those in the Guidelines even though this is the very topic of the preceding three paragraphs.  It seems that this needs to be added.

3\) "TEI Conformant" is defined in §23.3 in a way that requires conformance to the TEI Abstract Model, but the last paragraph of §23.3.3.1 says that a document conforms to the TEI Abstract Model if it's encoded according to a valid TEI Conformant schema.  I believe we have a circular definition.

3\) Minor copyedits to §23.3.3.1:

\* Insert a comma after "expressed in the TEI scheme by the p element".

\* Change all "Docbook" to "DocBook".

\* "it is not itself conformant" --> "it is not itself necessarily conformant"

posts.text:
1\. Standardised on "TEI Abstract Model" where this is used as a term
2\. Reworded to clarify.
3\. No, it says you must do both. Conformance to the TAM is necessary but not sufficient.
3 \(bis\) Looking at the sentence again, I removed the first comma since the "expressed ... element" clause is not parenthetical
Docbook -> DocBook and added "itself" 

Last para now reads

<p>A document is said to conform to the <term>TEI Abstract
Model</term> if features for which an encoding is proposed by the TEI
Guidelines are encoded within it using the markup and other syntactic
properties defined by means of a valid <term>TEI Conformant</term>
schema. Hence, even though the names of elements or attributes may
vary, a TEI Conformant document must respect the TEI Semantic Model,
and be valid with respect to a TEI Conformant Schema. Although it may
be possible to transform a document which follows the <term>TEI Abstract
Model</term> into a <term>TEI Conformant</term> document, such a
document is not itself necessarily conformant.</p>
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #161 TEI Abstract Model

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #161 TEI Abstract Model

tickets.description:
I notice that both <state> and <trait> can have datable attributes on them even though <trait> is meant for properties that are "in principle" unchanging.  So at first it would seem that the datable attributes should not be allowed on <trait> unless we allow that certain traits may change but are still to be considered traits and not states.  Is the intention?

Further confusion comes from the example given in the Guidelines for <trait>, involving citizenship that lasted for only a certain period.  It seems to me that this example is more appropriate for the <state> element, unless this is an example of one of these traits not to be considered a state.

In short, a bit of clarification on the use of these elements would be good here.

posts.text: Dang, my login cookie must have expired.  This bug was submitted by me.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #168 state vs. trait

posts.text: That's OK Kevin, your style is instantly recognisable :-\)
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #168 state vs. trait

posts.text: The difference between state and trait is discussed in the "Basic Principles" section of chapter ND \(13.3.1\), where we do try to show that the distinction is not always entirely clear cut.  I think citizenship could qualify as a trait because it is externally defined and not conditioned by individual volition, but I can see why it might not be regarded as prototypical. I have therefore removed it from the example list for the moment. Do you have suggestions for how the discussion in "Basic Principles" could be improved? In general, we need more examples in this section: suggestions welcomed.

tickets.description: I would like the Guidelines to explain when to use the <sex> element as a child of <person> versus using the sex attribute on the person element.

posts.text: What would you suggest as an explanation? As elsewhere, the attreibute is used to provide a normalised "coded" view of something which can be discussed in more detail or less exactly or in a different language as the content of the element.  And it's not necessarily an either/or situation -- you might well choose to supply both e.g. <person sex="m"><sex notBefore="1989-12-11">male following successful operation in 1989</sex>
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #169 use of <sex> vs. <person sex="___">

posts.text: I understand that you have to use <sex> if you want to provide a free-text description, but I wonder when you should use @sex on person when you could simply provide a child element sex with @value.  That is, what's the difference between \(a\) <person sex="1"> and \(b\) <person> with a child element <sex value="1"/>?  We have two different ways of encoding the same information in a machine-readable way with no discussion in the Guidelines \(that I see\) about why you might chose one over the other.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #169 use of <sex> vs. <person sex="___">

posts.text: There is a backwards compatibility issue here. Eearlier  versions of the Guidelines had a small number of predefined attributes for <person> \(of which sex was one\), intended to make it easier to categorise <persons> for example in a language corpus.  I agree that it's mildly confusing to have two ways of doing the same thing, but if all you want to record about a person is their name, ageGroup, and sex, it seems much more convenient to do it by means of the attributes on person than by adding three rather verbose child elements.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #169 use of <sex> vs. <person sex="___">

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #169 use of <sex> vs. <person sex="___">

posts.text:
I agree with your point about convenience when all you want to give is a person's name, age group, and sex.  I'm skeptical that many projects will record no more than this information about speakers.

In any case, I still would like the Guidelines to give guidance on which option to choose for a new project.  Aside from backwards compatibility, is there any grounds for preferring one over another?  If not, I would at least like explicit mention of two ways to record the same information.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #169 use of <sex> vs. <person sex="___">

posts.text: Agreed that Guidelines need some sentences to explain possible use cases
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #169 use of <sex> vs. <person sex="___">

posts.text:
Revised start of NDPERSE to read:

... In addition, a small number of very commonly used personal properties
may be recorded using  attributes specific to <gi>person</gi> \(and
<gi>personGrp</gi>\) <specList><specDesc key="person"
atts="role sex age"/></specList></p>

<p>These attributes are intended for use where only a small amount of
data is to be encoded in a more or less normalised form, possibly for
many person elements, for example when encoding basic facts about
respondents to a questionnaire. When however a more detailed encoding
is required for all kinds of information about a person, for
example in a historical gazeteer, then it will be more appropriate to
use the elements <gi>age</gi>, <gi>sex</gi> and others described
elsewhere in this chapter.</p>

As per
http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1003&L=TEI-L&T=0&O=D&P=162
and
http://listserv.brown.edu/archives/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1003&L=TEI-L&D=0&O=D&T=0&P=288
Roma exits with a fatal error when processing an ODD where <valList> contains unexpected text nodes \(i.e., whitespace\) instead of just <valItem>s.

Possible solutions might involve the use of getElementsByTagName\('valItem'\) or
if \($oChild->nodeName=='valItem'\) \{ ... \}

posts.text: - **milestone**: 871214 --> ROMA
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #172 Processing of <valList>

posts.text:
A first priority would be to change the definition of term to make it independant of a definition.
I don't like so much \(A\) since it creates an implicit list by the sole 'sibling' relation between nodes. I would also not like to lose the use of <term> which should indeed mark terms \(in the sense of ISO 704\). My suggestion would either to:
avide to use <term> within <item> when applicale, or,
to use <term> within <list> \(but this is probably too narrow a use case to go in this direction; or we should have to consider mixing this with <gloss>, <label>, etc.\)
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.text:
At the NZETC we are inconsistent about how we do this \(see http://www.nzetc.org/tei-source/HutColl.xml for an example\).

The fact that <keywords> uses the plural, makes it an implicit list, to my eye.
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.text:
Lou wrote "I don't see what's wrong with using <term> this way".  I believe that means he is not opposed to \(A\), whereas Laurent and Stuart expressed support for \(B\) over \(A\).

Unrelated to my original question, Lou suggested that the example given in the element defintion for <keywords> could be changed to to tag "Mathematicians - Great Britain - Biography" as three separate <term>s, all within one <item>.  These terms comprise a compound subject heading, and determining what counts as a subject heading term \(each atomic unit or the compound term\) is an ontological debate that I'd like to avoid.

However, if we end up tightening up the content model of <keyword> to allow only \(A\) or \(B\), we should make sure to still allow <term> within <item> to allow for Lou's ontology of subject headings.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.text:
Council agreed to deprecate" use of  <list> in <keywords>.  All examples involving <keywords> in the 
Guidelines will be changed to use only <term>, and prose note\(s\) will be added to clarify that <term> is preferred.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.text: For future reference, note that use of <term> has the further advantage of allowing @target, with which one can point to an authority record for a term from a controlled vocabulary.
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #173 distinguishing two ways to encode <keywords>

posts.text:
Heterodox examples duly removed. Added following comment to <keywords> reference:
<p>Each individual  keyword \(including compound subject headings\) should
be supplied as a <gi>term</gi> element directly within the
<gi>keywords</gi>  element. An alternative usage, in which each
<gi>term</gi> appears within a <gi>item</gi> inside a <gi>list</gi> is
permitted for backwards compatibility, but is deprecated.</p></remarks>

tickets.description: §2.4.3 says that the value of keywords@scheme points to taxonomy@xml:id; however, the example in the element definition of <keywords> contains an absolute URI in keywords@scheme.  This seems like an entirely appropriate use of keywords@scheme, so I suggest revising §2.4.3 to mention this possibility explicitly and no longer imply that you need to include a taxonomy for any keyword scheme which as been defined with an absolute URI.

posts.text: @scheme, like any other TEI pointer, can refer either to a locally supplied element, or to an external URL. The real problem here is that <taxonomy> may be used in two different ways, either to supply an authority list, or to supply a bibliographic citation to one. At rev 7389, I have revised the text to distinguish these possibilities a bit better, updated some of the URIs to more plausible ones and added another example. However this whole section needs some rethinking to enable TEI to leverage the greater availability of linked data these days.

tickets.description:
I found that when generating HTML documentation, my examples in my ODD were losing the namespace prefixes from attributes in my namespace. I've poked around, and found that namespace URIs are mapped to prefixes in the template "verbatim-getNamespacePrefix" in the file Stylesheets/common2/verbatim.xsl. I found that if I added an <xsl:when> for my namespace I got the desired results. It doesn't look like there is any parameterization mechanism for me to provide this on the roma commandline.
I'm not sure how to solve the general-case problem \(or maybe it's already solved and I don't know about it?\), but at the very least, ISO Schematron should be added to the list of hard-coded namespaces.

posts.text: I spent some time on verbatim.xsl last week, and it should now behave better; it will add namespace prefixes \_if\_ the source document declares them, and it will add the apppropriate decls to the output.

tickets.description:
3.11.2.1 of the Guidelines:

http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html\#COBICOL

suggests that the three levels of bibliographic item, analyitic, monographic and series, MUST be distinguished in <biblStruct>, and MAY be distinguished in <bibl>. However, currently only <series> is available in <bibl>; <monogr> and <analytic> are not. I think the ability to distinguish these bibliographic levels in <bibl> is important, so this deficiency should be rectified, for consistency with <series> and with the Guidelines.

posts.text: Is the distinction made by the @level on <title> not sufficient for <bibl>?
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
The issue is that without some kind of bracketing mechanism, it can be difficult to tell what elements of a reference belong with the analytic, the monogr or the series. The use-case I'm concerned with is where <bibl> is used to mark up an existing bibliographic reference which is formatted according to a style guide; the order of elements is then dictated by the style guide, and this can make for difficulty figuring out what belongs with what, because style guides are sometimes guided by custom rather than rational organization. 

But over and above that, the guidelines already say we should be able to use <analytic> and <monogr> in <bibl>, and we can't. I think the guidelines are right and the schema is wrong; they're useful and should be available.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
But if you want to mark up a pre-existing formatted bibliog reference what guarantee have you that the components of <analytic> or <monogr> will be in the right order, or even contiguous? 

The passage you reference reads "<p>These three levels may be distinguished within a <gi>bibl</gi>
element, and must be distinguished within a <gi>biblStruct</gi> element
by means of the following elements" I would prefer to rewrite it as follows:

<p>These three levels may be distinguished within any bibliographic element. Within the <gi>bibl</gi>
element, the status of particular parts must be inferred \(for example by use of the <att>level</ attribute on <gi>title</gi>. Within  a <gi>biblStruct</gi> element however, they are explicitly distinguished by means of the following elements:

I think we also need to add something to the discussion of punctuation, \(to say that it must be supplied within bibl\) but that's a separate issue.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
>But if you want to mark up a pre-existing formatted bibliog reference what
>guarantee have you that the components of <analytic> or <monogr> will be in
>the right order, or even contiguous? 

No absolute guarantee, but they usually are -- otherwise humans would find them hard to parse out. Here's an example:

<bibl type="article" subtype="book\_chapter" xml:id="carlin\_2003">
<author><name><surname>Carlin</surname> \(<forename>Claire</forename>\)</name></author>, <title level="a">The Staging of Impotence : France’s last <hi rend="italic">congrès</hi></title>

dans 

<title level="m">Theatrum mundi : studies in honor of Ronald W. Tobin</title>, éd. <editor><name><forename>Claire</forename> <surname>Carlin</surname></name></editor> et <editor><name><forename>Kathleen</forename> <surname>Wine</surname></name></editor>, <pubPlace>Charlottesville, Va.</pubPlace>, <publisher>Rookwood Press</publisher>, <date when="2003">2003</date>.

</bibl>

The first block is <analytic>, the second <monogr>.

With regard to punctuation, I don't think we should particularly prescribe that punctuation \_must\_ be supplied in <bibl>; we should just say that it usually is. It's more than conceivable that people will use <bibl> for structured references because they find that the constraints of <biblStruct> make it impractical.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: Proposal is to revise the wording to make clear that <analytic> and <monogr> as grouping elements are available only in biblStruct; and to discuss how to do analogous things in <bibl>
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: I think Lou's proposal does not match what Martin asks for: that <analytic> and <monogr> be included in the content model for <bibl>.  And it's not clear what sort of prose Lou would add about "how to do analogous things in <bibl>".  How would you?  Martin shows that you encode all the pieces without any container elements, so processing to find the piece you want is difficult.  I can't come up with any good reason not to allow <analytic> and <monogr> in <bibl> when <series> is already allowed there.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: Yes, Lou's proposal is not what I originally wanted; all it does is to clarify that what I originally wanted is not available. That's a disappointment from my point of view, since I still think <monogr> and <analytic> should be available in <bibl>. I agreed with the proposal since it clarifies an currently confusing situation, but I still don't see the principle behind Lou's objection to the original idea.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: BTW. What I meant is that if we go the way you want, Martin, we would have to make analytic and monogr become mixed content which would create a mess for the management of really structured bibliography.
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: I like Laurent's compromise: it provides the grouping functionality we need without complicating the situation for <biblStruct>. Can we make this the proposal, along with suitable updates the Guidelines?
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
I've always liked the idea of allowing <bibl> inside <bibl>, so Laurent's proposal gets two firm thumbs-up from me.

\(I'd also like a more elegant way to record the fact that a bibliographic reference is a shorter version of an item in my master bibliography, currently <bib><ptr target="\#abc"/></bibl> \[such as @ref on bibl\], but I suspect this is a very different discussion.\)

No to Lou's suggestion to resolve this by simply clarifying the existing guielines, therefore.
posts.author: gabrielbodard
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: I'm fine with Laurent's compromise as well.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
Thanks for the examples.  When Martin wrote "nested-like-biblStruct \(analytic sibling of <biblStruct>", I think he meant "nested-like-biblStruct \(analytic sibling of monogr\)".

I don't see how "analytic contained by monogr" matches reality better than "analytic sibling of monogr".  I think we're getting into the territory of text ontology \(does the sentence end before the end of the blockquote?  who knows?\), so for consistency with biblStruct, it seems that that we should go with analytic sibling of monogr.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
Yes, I did mean "nested-like-biblStruct \(analytic sibling of monogr\)". Sorry\!

By matching reality, I meant that \(e.g.\) chapters are contained by books, so chapter \(analytic\) bibls should be contained by book \(monogr\) bibls. This has always seemed logical to me. But it's an issue more for the guidelines and examples; we should decide which approach we're going to exemplify, but whatever we put in the guidelines, I'll still be free to model reality my way.
posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text: Now I understand what Martin meant by reality; however, I don't think of metadata about the article as being a nested component of metadata about a journal issue.  So I still prefer to do it like biblStruct.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.author: martindholmes
posts.subject: #185 <monogr> and <analytic> should be allowed in <bibl>

posts.text:
EDIT:

Allow <bibl> AS a child of <bibl>...

tickets.description:
The discussion of sourceDesc currently doesn't seem to have any mention of the fact that sourceDesc is \(and has been since at least P3 if not earlier\) repeatable. The Best Practice for TEI in Libraries on the TEI Wiki recommends using multiple sourceDescs for multiple sources but there is nothing about this in the Guidelines as far as I can see. Another option, obviously, in such cases is to use a single sourceDesc and a listBibl inside with multiple bibl elements.  It is interesting the the Libraries SIG has chosen to recommend the first of these methods, and I assume that this is more consistent with library practice. 

Regardless, there should be discussion of the use of multiple sourceDesc elements in the Guidelines.

-James

posts.text: It is worth noting that <sourceDesc> is a member of att.declarable. This allows for different portions of the document \(i.e., different descendants of <text>\) to self-associate with a particular <sourceDesc> by pointing at it with their decls= attribute.
posts.author: sbauman
posts.subject: #195 sourceDesc discussion and repeatability

posts.text: bibll, biblStruct, listBibl, and even biblFull are all also members of att.declarable, so it is perfectly feasible to use a single sourceDesc containing a listBibl \(or several liostBibls\), each of which \(or their components\) can be associated with a declaring element, at whatever  granularity is appropriate. So this doesn't seem like an argument for the necessity of supporting multiple sourceDescs to me.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #195 sourceDesc discussion and repeatability

posts.text:
While not really an argument for continuing supporting it: that the Libraries SIG recommend this practice, and that TEI has supported it since at least P3 \(if not earlier\) means that it will be a significant change to \*stop\* supporting it. \(I.e. breakage of backwards compatibility\)  All I'm asking for is a sentence or two mentioning a\) that multiple sourceDescs are possible \(perhaps contrasted with using a single sourceDesc/listBibl\) and b\) what it \_means\_ when there are more than one sourceDesc.

-j
posts.author: jcummings
posts.subject: #195 sourceDesc discussion and repeatability

posts.text:
I have added the following text

<p>A single electronic text may be derived from multiple source
documents, in whole or in part. The <gi>sourceDesc</gi> may therefore
contain a <gi>listBibl</gi> element grouping together <gi>bibl</gi>,
<gi>biblStruct</gi>, or <gi>msDesc</gi> elements for each of the
sources concerned. It is also possible to repeat the
<gi>sourceDesc</gi> element in such a case.  The <att>decls</att>
attribute described in section <ptr target="\#CCAS"/> may be used to
associate parts of the encoded text with the bibliographic element
from which it derives in either case. </p>

I wish the Libraries SIG would express an opinion on this topic. I would really like to deprecate the practice of supplying multiple sourceDescs, unless there is a convincing case for not doing so.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #195 sourceDesc discussion and repeatability

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> closed
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #195 sourceDesc discussion and repeatability

tickets.description:
<particDesc> is the recommended place to put a <listPerson> containing references to people mentioned in a text but the definition of <particDesc> says: 
"\(participation description\) describes the identifiable speakers, voices, or other participants in a linguistic interaction."

I would hold that with this definition it is \_wrong\_ to put <person> elements here which are people who are not speakers/voices/participants in a linguistic interaction. Given that <listPerson> is being often used to record information about people mentioned in texts which in most people's minds would not count as 'a linguistic interaction', I propose that either:

a\) This definition be broadened so that it is clear that historical references to people in \*ANY\* text are able to be here, or 
b\) Another location is firmly and categorically recommended for <person>s which are not "speakers in a linguistic interaction" perhaps also suitable for storage of <listPlace>, <listOrg> and <listEvent>. i.e. a single place for all such records of people/places/organizations/events mentioned in the document.

If a\) I would suggest something along the lines of:
"\(participation description\) describes the identifiable people, speakers, or other participants in a text."

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> AMBER

posts.subject: #201 particDesc def'n need sto broadened?

posts.text: Wording change to particDesc desc has been adopted., so closing this.

tickets.summary: Setting latexPaperSize to "letterpaper" yields bad LaTeX
tickets.description:
== Summary ==

Setting latexPaperSize to "letterpaper" yields incorrect LaTeX code.

== Versions ==

Ubuntu 10.4

I can reproduce the problem with this version:

$ dpkg-query -W tei-p5-xsl2
tei-p5-xsl2     5.33

\(I believe this bug is not present in released versions prior to 5.33.\)

And I can also reproduce it with the latest version of the trunk in SVN:

$ svn update
At revision 7876.

== How to Reproduce ==

1\. Download the attached zip file.

2\. Unzip.

3\. Edit the Makefile so that STYLE points to where your copy of the XSLT 2 version of the LaTeX stylesheet is.  \(To reproduce the bug for sure, you should use either one of the two versions I indicate above.\)

4\. Execute 

$ make

== Actual Results ==

LaTeX fails with the following error message:

\! Dimension too large.
l.129    \paperheight
279
? 

== Expected Results ==

LaTeX should run without problem.

== Observations ==

Setting the value of latexPaperSize to a3paper or a5paper also yield the same type of error.

It is possible to work around the bug by setting latexPaperSize to an empty value and using latexGeometryOptions to set the paper size.

e.g:

<xsl:param name="latexGeometryOptions" select="'letterpaper,centering'"/>
<xsl:param name="latexPaperSize" select="''"/>

Note that in this case, the stylesheet does not generate code to set \paperheight and \paperwidth. I have not observed any problem due to this workaround so the question for me is why have the stylesheet set \paperheight and \paperwidth? Is the geometry package not doing it properly?

posts.text: files illustrating the problem
posts.author: lddubeau
posts.subject: #210 Setting latexPaperSize to "letterpaper" yields bad LaTeX

posts.text: oh dear, that is embarassing, sorry. I missed out "mm" after the dimensions. fixed in subversion for next release \(hopefully later today\)
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #210 Setting latexPaperSize to "letterpaper" yields bad LaTeX

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed

posts.subject: #210 Setting latexPaperSize to "letterpaper" yields bad LaTeX

tickets.summary: cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output
tickets.description:
== Summary ==

If a table contains in its first row a cell which spans multiple columns AND the multi-column cell is followed by a cell, running the XSLT version 2 stylesheets on an XML document conforming to a vanilla TEI schema results in incorrect LaTeX code.

This bug is related to bug number 3007060. I was not able to reopen this old bug, so I'm filing a new one.

== Versions ==

Ubuntu 10.4

$ dpkg-query -W tei-p5-xsl2
tei-p5-xsl2     5.33

== How to Reproduce ==

1\. Download the attached zip file.

2\. Unzip.

3\. Edit the Makefile so that STYLE points to where your copy of the XSLT 2 version of the LaTeX stylesheet is.

4\. Execute 

$ make

== Actual Results ==

Results in the following error at the stage of running LaTeX on the output of the XSL transformation:

\! Extra alignment tab has been changed to \cr.
<template> \endtemplate 

l.302 ...olor\{label\}\}c\}\{cell 2 spans 2\}\tabcellsep
cell 3\end\{tabular\}

== Expected Results ==

There should be no error. That is, correct LaTeX code should be generated.

== Observations ==

When processing test.xml, the XSL stylesheet creates an intermediary structure of cell elements:

<cell col="n">x</cell>

Hypothesis: under some conditions, two different cell elements may get the same value of "n" for the col attribute.  However, only one of these will be used to produce the preamble and thus the table will be missing one cell. \(This is an hypothesis based on mentally walking through the figures.xsl file bundled with the package tei-p5-xsl2.\)

posts.text: files illustrating the problem
posts.author: lddubeau
posts.subject: #211 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

posts.text:
Oops... I've just realized test.xml is an invalid file due to the presence of the "align" attributes on the cells.

This can easily be fixed by removing the offending attributes. The resulting file is valid and the result of processing is the same.
posts.author: lddubeau
posts.subject: #211 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

posts.text: Good lord. The algorithm in figures.xsl is ridiculous. It could never work. Working on it.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #211 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

posts.text: reimplemented the template which works out the preamble, and it seems OK now.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #211 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed

posts.subject: #211 cell spanning columns generates bad LaTeX output

tickets.summary: stylesheets support the align attribute inconsistently
tickets.description:
== Summary ==

The align attribute on table rows and cells is inconsistently handled.

== Versions ==

Ubuntu 10.4

$ dpkg-query -W tei-p5-xsl2
tei-p5-xsl2     5.33

== How to Reproduce ==

1\. Download the attached zip file.

2\. Unzip.

3\. Edit the Makefile so that STYLE points to where your copy of the XSLT 2 version of the LaTeX stylesheet is.

4\. Execute 

$ make

Note that test.xml is valid according to the myTEI.rnc bundled in the zip file. This schema allows an additional align attribute on cell elements. The specification for this attribute was derived from the code in figures.xsl.

== Expected Results ==

The test.xml file contains 5 tables:

1\. Titled "Default" which has no align attribute.

2\. Titled "Left" which has the middle cell with the attribute "align" set to "left".

3\. Titled "Center" which has the middle cell with the attribute "align" set to "center".

4\. Titled "Right" which has the middle cell with the attribute "align" set to "Right".

5\. Titled "Center w/o role attribute on cell" with has the middle cell with the attribute "align" set to "center".

I would expect the following:

1\. Table 1 and 2 should look the same because "Left" alignment is the default.

2\. Table 2, 3 and 4 should look different because the alignment of the middle cell is different. In other words, changing the alignment should change the alignment and nothing else.

3\. Table 5 should look the same as table 3. As per the TEI documentation on the "role" attribute, when role is set on a row, all the cells of this row have the role of the row, unless overridden on the cell themselves.

== Actual Results ==

The expectations in the previous section are not met.

== Observations ==

The upshot of all this is twofold:

1\. The align attribute results in \*differences\* in the LaTeX code generated \*only when\* the "role" attribute is set to "label" on the cells where specific alignments are desired.

2\. The LaTeX code generated by the stylesheet does not result in the expected aesthetic differences.

I realize align is not part of TEI proper but looking at figures.xsl, it seems that the intent behind implementing code for an align attribute is not being realized in a consistent way.

Incidentally, it seems that the fo2 code handles alignment in a way which is not compatible with the latex2 code. There, the relevant attribute is called halign, for one thing.

posts.subject: #212 stylesheets support the align attribute inconsistently

posts.text:
I have added support for @align on all cells, and it appears to work.

fo2 stylesheet adjusted accordingly.

with thanks as usual for excellent bug reports\!

posts.subject: #212 stylesheets support the align attribute inconsistently

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-fixed

tickets.summary: loss of enumeration for attrs in DTDs
tickets.description:
The attached ODD — which was generated with web Roma and then tweaked for human readability — demonstrates the problem. An attribute \(in this case type= of <div>\) is constrained to a closed enumerated list. The RELAX NG schema correctly models this. The DTD, however, has the attribute defined as NMTOKEN instead of an appropriate closed list.

I have tested this using web Roma, commandline roma against P5 1.7.0 and stylesheets from 2010-07-07, and P5 & stylesheets of SF version r7903.

It does not seem to matter whether or not there is a "<datatype> <rng:ref name='data.enumerated'/> </datatype>" or not.

tickets.summary: New and old style ODD produce inconsistent outputs
tickets.description: An ODD which defines a schema by inclusion generates a schema which is different from one defined by exclusion, even if the elements contained by both are identical. Compare the schemas generated from teilite.odd and teilite\_ns.odd in P5/Exemplars: in the latter, components of the various model.foo\_sequence patterns are given in alpha order, in the former they are given in order of declaration. This means that a document which conforms to the schema generated for one won't conform to the schema generated for the other. It's debatable which is right, but they ought to be consistent. Unless we claim that the "order of declaration" default was a bug.

posts.text: Ah\! The order is determined by the order of the <elementRef>s in the ODD file. I had sorted them alphabetically in my test file, so it's not surprising they come out in that order.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #218 New and old style ODD produce inconsistent outputs

posts.text: - **status**: open --> closed-invalid
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #218 New and old style ODD produce inconsistent outputs

tickets.summary: Schematron code showing in Appendix C
tickets.description:
For a handful of elements, there is a bit of Schematron code that intervenes between the "Declaration" and the grey box containing the example. Here's the list of elements with this problem:
TEI
addSpan
constraintSpan
damageSpan
delSpan
dimensions
moduleRef
msIdentifier
ptr
relatedItem
relation

posts.text: Yes, that is deliberate: it's not a bug. The schematron constraints are applied to the element content by a conformant schema processor and form part of the semantics of the element concerned. In the past we've expressed such constraints informally in the prose text of the Guidelines only; with the availability of Schematron it's possible to add automatic checking for some of them, and it's likely that we'll continue to add more in the future.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #219 Schematron code showing in Appendix C

posts.text:
- **milestone**:  --> GREEN
- **status**: open --> closed-wont-fix

posts.subject: #219 Schematron code showing in Appendix C

tickets.description:
We replaced model.graphicLike in char and glyph with figure, and then I later made a good argument on another ticket for adding it back to char, which was accepted and duly done. However, char and glyph work in very similar ways and if it is justifiable for char to have model.graphicLike then glyph should have it as well.  

Recommendation: restore model.graphicLike to glyph, keeping figure as well, as is the case in char.

On a second note:

Content model of char is: 

element char
\{
att.global.attributes,
\(
charName?,
model.glossLike\*,
charProp\*,
mapping\*,
figure\*,
model.graphicLike\*,
model.noteLike\*
\)
\}

Content model of glyph is: 
element glyph
\{
att.global.attributes,
\(
glyphName?,
model.glossLike\*,
charProp\*,
mapping\*,
figure\*,
model.noteLike\*
\)
\}

Commonalities: model.glossLike, charProp, mapping, figure, \(model.graphicLike\), model.noteLike.

Is there any reason we're not using a class to provide \(some of\) these?

-james

posts.text: Proposal is to add model.graphicLike to glyph for consistency with figure

tickets.summary: when and where to capture line breaks
tickets.description: Tite says "If line breaks are to be captured, use the lb  element" but does not explain under what circumstances line breaks are to be captured outside of verse \(where it's discussed in relation to <l>\).  This should be clarified.

posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #228 when and where to capture line breaks

posts.text: - **summary**: Tite: when to capture line breaks --> when to capture line breaks
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #228 when and where to capture line breaks

posts.text:
IMHO line breaks need to be captured in prose \(or text where verse lines are \*not\* indicated\) only in the following situations:

\- where the layout is clearly purposeful, e.g. because it forms a pattern or acrostic, or on a title page whose components are not otherwise distinguished

\- where a word has been broken across a line \(with or without hyphenation\)

But in general, I can't see much value in it if you are going to the trouble of capturing semantic markup such as verse lines, list items, paragraphs etc.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #228 when and where to capture line breaks

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> kshawkin

tickets.summary: No documentation for attributes not in a class
tickets.description:
In the HTML and PDF documentation generated by Roma, there are no entries for attributes that are not in an attribute class. For example, @cRef is an attribute defined for <ref>, but it is not a member of an attribute class. In the Roma-generated documentation for a given TEI schema, @cRef is not documented \(except that it appears in the "Declaration" section showing the formal declaration for <ref>\). This differs from the online Guidelines at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/index.html, where each reference page includes a section labeled "In addition to global attributes", which not only indicates the relevant attribute classes but also documents any individual, not-in-a-class attributes.

This is particularly problematic when a project adds a new, project-specific attribute for an existing element. If the attribute is not added as a member of a class, that attribute is not documented anywhere other than the ODD source for the project's schema \(since of course it's not something one can look up on the relevant reference page of the online TEI Guidelines\).

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> rahtz

tickets.description: Chapter 9 is about "This chapter defines a module for encoding human-oriented monolingual and multilingual dictionaries, glossaries, and similar documents." but in the definition of 'entry' and friends only dictionaries are mentioned. The element pages for 'entry' 'superEntry' and 'entryFree' need to be changed from talking about dictionaries to talking about 'human-oriented monolingual and multilingual dictionaries, glossaries, and similar documents'

posts.text: If we could agree that the chapter is about \(semasiological\) lexical resources at large. We could introduce in the introduction of the chapter a definition for lexical resource  \(relating also to ISO LMF\) and use the term "lexical resource" all over the place in the various specifications for entry, entryFree, etc. I must say I read 'dictionary' in this quite general sense. \(http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00436328/fr/\)
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
I completely agree. "Lexical resource" is better than my suggestion \(which was merely about foolish consistency not correctness / accuracy / clarity / usefulness\).

Even better, maybe we could even lift \(with reference\) the definition of lexical resource from the standard, then we could solve both the problem of finding the best wording and and referencing the appropriate ISO standard. I tried to access the standard, but it appears to be behind a paywall http://www.iso.org/iso/catalogue\_detail.htm?csnumber=37327 .
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
I agree that i\) "dictionary" in the element pages reads like a general cover-term as opposed to the more specific \(and not so easy to restrictively define\) sense in the passage quoted by Stuart, and that ii\) "lexical resource" is better, even without quoting the definition \(just saying "a module for encoding human-oriented monolingual and multilingual dictionaries, glossaries, and similar documents, for which a general cover-term 'lexical resources' will be used below". 

But the relevant ISO spec must have an older publicly-accessible version somewhere at http://www.tc37sc4.org/ -- right, Laurent?
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text: I actually sent a recent draft to Stuart...
posts.author: romary
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
Reading a draft of the standard \(and confirming with the OED\), 'lexical resource' is the correct generic term to replace 'dictionary' and 'lexcial entry' for 'dictionary entry.' 'Lexicon' in both the standard and the OED implies a single language or selection criteria which doesn't apply \(for example\) to multi-lingual thesauri or bilingual dictionaries.  

The standard doesn't appear to contain a free-standing definition of  lexical resource.
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text: - **status**: open --> open-accepted
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text: Is the recommendation to globally replace "dictionary" by "lexical resource" in this chapter? that seems a bit excessive, since some of the time we are really talking about dictionaries here, and most of the examples are actually from print dictionaries.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
There's "lexical database" too.

Looking at this from the distance of several months, I think I'd rather have a slightly extended introduction mentioning the terms "lexical resource" and "lexical database" \(I recall my abstract for TEI-MM-2010 getting criticised for the use of the term "lexical database", so maybe the term is worth mentioning here in the broad sense used by Laurent in many of his publications, including encyclopaedia chapters\) and then I think it might sound unnatural to kick out all the instances of "dictionary" given that we agree that dictionaries are one kind of lexical resources. However, Stuart's original point concerned the element pages, and there I think the change may be useful to have. 

To make sure: not within the chapter, but in the element pages, I think it might make sense to either replace "dictionary" altogether or to use "lexical resource/database" alongside it, e.g., in the definition for "entry", instead of "contains a reasonably well-structured dictionary entry", we could have "contains a reasonably well-structured entry in a lexical resource, e.g. a dictionary". Hmm. It feels a bit overpedantic, but I may be having a bad day. OTOH, maybe this is exactly the place to be pedantic.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
I think we're playing with semantics and words here \(words which already mean too many things to too many people to make this productive\). I think we need to look at what these things \(tei:entry based docs\) share in common and what the border cases might might be.

To my mind, non-tei:entry based documents are essentially linear texts designed to be accessed in a linear fashion. tei:entry based documents are works composed of semi-autonomous fragments which stand independently and which are designed to be accessed in any order. 

The border cases that I can think of include: "Choose Your Own Adventure" which are printed hypertexts designed to be accessed in non-linear order; The TEI standard which has chapters which are linear and entries which are designed for random access; encyclopedia in which topics are ordered / written to improve the flow between entries.
posts.author: stuartyeates
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
It is the business of the Guidelines to "play with semantics" as Stuart rather dismissively says. This chapter was originally written for the specific use case of the encoding of existing print dictionaries, as its current emphasis and language make abundantly clear. The original plan was to complement that with a different chapter on what were then known as "computational lexica", but which might also be thought of as "born digital dictionaries", but that chapter never materialised. \(Buy me a pint and I'll tell you who to blame\)  Subsequently, however, people have found that they can actually use quite a lot of the existing print focussed chapoter for non print artefacts quite successfully \(e.g. Piotr\). 

So I repeat my earlier assertion that the simplest way of addressing the reasonable concernsoriginally raised by this ticket is not to rewrite the entire chapter, but rather to provide a section in the existing one describing how to apply the tags defined to non print lexical resources. Freedict would be one good example but I am sure you can think of  others. Someone needs to volunteer to do this and produce a draft.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
It is the business of the Guidelines to "play with semantics" as Stuart rather dismissively says. This chapter was originally written for the specific use case of the encoding of existing print dictionaries, as its current emphasis and language make abundantly clear. The original plan was to complement that with a different chapter on what were then known as "computational lexica", but which might also be thought of as "born digital dictionaries", but that chapter never materialised. \(Buy me a pint and I'll tell you who to blame\)  Subsequently, however, people have found that they can actually use quite a lot of the existing print focussed chapoter for non print artefacts quite successfully \(e.g. Piotr\). 

So I repeat my earlier assertion that the simplest way of addressing the reasonable concernsoriginally raised by this ticket is not to rewrite the entire chapter, but rather to provide a section in the existing one describing how to apply the tags defined to non print lexical resources. Freedict would be one good example but I am sure you can think of  others. Someone needs to volunteer to do this and produce a draft.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text: Indeed I sort of volunteer and want to produce a draft. "Sort of", because this is the topic of a grant proposal I'm currently writing \(overwriting: it's become a booklet and I'm still not done\). If the grant is approved, I will be able to start around October at the earliest, so I'm not sure how this corresponds to the time frames for updating the Guidelines, the more so that October is only a \(potential\) starting point. The grant addresses the Dictionaries chapter directly.
posts.author: bansp
posts.subject: #236 definition of 'entry'

posts.text:
Pending further work on the chapter,  at rev 8871 revised <desc>s as follows:

<entry>contains a single structured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such
as a dictionary or lexicon

<entryFree>contains a single structured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such
as a dictionary or lexicon

<super|Entry>groups a sequence of entries within any kind of lexical resource, such
as a dictionary or lexicon which function as a single unit, for
example a set of homographs

tickets.description:
I've been playing around with indexing documents and have been using xml:id attributes in the <p> tags as the target of <ref> tags in the index. Paragraphs seemed to be a more meaningful semantic target than page in an electronic based document. The stylesheet doesn't pass the xml:id attribute through so the index gets built but the targets don't exist in the xhtml version. Is it possible to add an option to pass pre generated xml:ids through? Or is there a more widly accepted work flow for building indexes in electronic documents?

Thanks Again

Gary

tickets.description:
Two nearly identical scripts exist for P4 to P5 transduction:

http://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/tei/trunk/P4toP5/

http://tei.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/tei/trunk/Stylesheets/profiles/default/p4/

The main difference between them is that one is XSLT 1.0, and the other 2.0, which basically means that the former uses some extension functions. And it recently got some templates for CES and OTA, which probably illustrates my point very well, because it shows that the scripts drift apart, the 2.0 version, part of the Stylesheets package, not having the functionality that the 1.0 script has now, but being generally newer and described with oXygen documentation elements, which the 1.0 script lacks in turn.

Maybe one of them should go, or, if you want to maintain both 1.0 and 2.0 versions for some reason, perhaps they should become skeletons including the common subset of templates, for ease of maintenance.

posts.text: Point taken. I have taken the extra bits over to the 2.0 version, which I shall try to maintain. I have put a message in the other saying it is deprecated. I'll see about getting rid of it one day.

posts.text:
I don't see the semantics of mode="replace" for memberOf. Either an element belongs to a class or not. If not:
\- mode="add" makes it a member
\- mode="delete" has no effect
If it did belong to the class in the source specification:
\- mode="add" has no effect
\- mode="delete" removes it from the class
or did you have another idea in mind?

tickets.summary: elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

posts.text: I.C. <relatedItem>: Mistakenly included in Tite.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #247 elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

posts.text: Redeclaring the ODD for Tite to use explicit inclusion of elements \(rather than deletion\) would be a good way of ensuring against future unintended inclusions. This was not possible when Tite was first defined, of course, but I would recommend using it now.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #247 elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

posts.text:
As you know, Kevin, we do not currently use Tite, but our
TCP \(and preceding\) schemes were, as I understand it, part
of the basis, or at least the background, for Tite. On 
those grounds, I'd point out ...

\(1\) that @role on <cell> \(and on <row>\) is very handy, 
almost essential in capturing tables. It is the
best way to capture the basic distinction between
a data cell and a heading cell \(or row\), i.e. between
an HTML <td> and <th>. It is well within the capability
of keying vendors to make this distinction most
of the time.

\(We also use @role="total" on cells and rows to
denote cells in arithmetical tables that contain
totals \(sums\), subtotals, products, etc., and are
often distinctively rendered and should be
distinctively displayed. This too is very useful.\)

\(2\) that @resp on <gap> and <unclear> serves to distinguish
omissions \(e.g. because of illegibility\) made by
the keying vendor from those made by the inhouse
editors. The former are presumably more likely to
be subject to further review, so it is a distinction
worth preserving, at least in some version of the
schema. \(You don't mention @resp as being among those
either removed or retained, so I do not know its
status.\)

\(3\) that you'll need some way to distinguish \(at least\)
in-line <figure>s from 'block' <figure>s of various
kinds. With @place removed, you're left accomplishing
this with @rend. That is how we do it, in fact, but is
is your intention to load @rend that way?

\(4\) that though we've used @extent on <gap> rather than
@unit/@quantity, we've been told that the latter would
have been a better choice: easier to process, at least.
Was the decision in favor of @extent an advised one?

That's all. The rest of the omissions would not affect us.

pfs
posts.author: pfschaffner
posts.subject: #247 elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

posts.text:
We have used cell/@role and q/@type as part of TEI Tite-based vendor conversion specs.

\-- David Sewell, U of Virginia
posts.author: dsew
posts.subject: #247 elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

posts.text:
In case it wasn't clear, my previous comment lists one more element \(<relatedItem>\) to remove from Tite.  We missed this in the previous list.

In my opinion based on comments above, the following should be retained in Tite \(that is, excluded from the list of things to remove\):

a\) cell/@role \(for the reasons Paul lists\)
b\) q/@type \(to distinguish block and inline quotations, I assume\)

Paul Schaffner argues for gap@resp and unclear@resp, but this assumes that both the vendor and in-house editors use the same schema.  It seems to me that Tite is designed only for use by vendors, so in-house staff would use a slightly looser schema that includes things like gap@resp and unclear@resp.  Therefore, I don't think we need to retain @resp on either of these elements.

Paul also comments on use of @extent vs. use of both @unit and @quantity on <gap>.  Tite includes gap@unit and gap@quantity, which he says is the generally advised way to do things, so I don't see any reason for us to object to getting rid of gap@extent.

It seems that Apex is not currently distinguishing between phrase-level \(in-line\) and chunk-level \(block\) <figure>s.  I welcome thoughts from others on whether we should retain figure@place in Tite to indicate this \(for any vendor that might want to do so\), or whether we should leave figure@rend for this.

I think we can all agree with Lou on rewriting the Tite ODD as he describes.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #247 elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #247 elements & attributes accidentally included in Tite 1.0

tickets.description:
The 'cert' attribute used by tei:date \(among other elements\) takes values from the enumeration data.certainty.  At http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-data.certainty.html that enumeration is documented as containing the values "high", "medium", "low", and "unknown".  As far as I can tell, however, nothing in the reference material says what those values mean.  For high, medium, and low it seems to be passably obvious, but does cert="uinknown" mean

\(a\) Lower than "low":  the certainty of this value is nil; the value is not known at all.  

\(b\) Not saying:  the certainty of this value may be high, or medium, or low; we don't know how certain it is.

Both \(a\) and \(b\) seem to me to be things one might wish to say, in different circumstances, so neither seems a priori impossible as an interpretation.  I think the Guidelines should say what the value means.

posts.text: I am pretty certain \(ha\) that "unknown" is for your case \(b\) -- i.e. we don't know what value is appropriate so we're not making any claim at all -- since this is how we use "unknown" in other enumerations. I will update the doc accordingly unless anyone wishes to argue otherwise.

posts.subject: #249 What does cert="unknown" mean?

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN

<val>unknown</val> should be used in cases where the encoder

tickets.description:
data.code is defined as xsd:anyURI and has been since P5 1.0.0

However none of the values described by these attributes are URIs.  

i.e. the prose, examples, and declared values are at odds with the defined datatype.

One solution is to redefine data.code as something else.

Another is to redefine the attributes with more appropriate datatypes. 

Sebastian recommends: 

" data.code should be abandoned
att.sourced/@ed   should be data.key
distinct/@time should be data.key
distinct/@space should be data.key
distinct/@social should be data.key
formula/@notation  should be data.pointer
msContents/@class   should be data.pointer
msItem/@class   should be data.pointer
msItemStruct/@class    should be data.pointer
writing/@source should be data.pointer
following the description of each attribute"

\(one to infinite of each of these I'm assuming\).

posts.text: Sebastian' recommendations make perfectly good sense to me. I think the confusion about "data.code" and what it means might then finally be laid to rest.

I agree with this. The solution would be to add <ref> and <ptr> to model.entryPart.top; that could be accomplished by making model.ptrLike.xml a member of model.entryPart.top -- in other words, add this:

tickets.summary: normalize attributes and classes on placeName/geogName
tickets.description:
I just received a request for tei:geogName to allow @cert \(as tei:placeName does\); this seemed a reasonable feature request to me, but before I posted it, I checked the two elements and found that their attribute class memberships were remarkably different. I can't see any good reason why any attribute available on placeName should not also be available on geogName. They are after all very very close to meaning the same thing.

As far as I can see, normalizing this would not harm geogName in any way \(in fact it would require one less bespoke attribute: @type\).

Any objections?

posts.text: The att class memberships of these elements is probably due for a careful check and tidyup, but the general principle is that the lower level components of names don'get encumbered with the same attributes as the upper ones, so as to avoid the possibility of contradicting one self. For example <surname> doesn't have all the same attributes as <persName>  -- rightly or wrongly the same model applies to <geogName> which is regarded as being a lower level component than <placeName>, presumably because the same placeName might contain both a geogName and a <country> etc. Arguably this is wrong, but that's the logic.
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #259 normalize attributes and classes on placeName/geogName

posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #259 normalize attributes and classes on placeName/geogName

posts.text: Agreed to add  geogName to same att classes as placeName, modulo observation that att.dimensions seems very implausible \(but it's on several others\)
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #259 normalize attributes and classes on placeName/geogName

posts.text:
- **milestone**: 871214 --> GREEN
- **assigned_to**: nobody --> louburnard

posts.subject: #259 normalize attributes and classes on placeName/geogName

posts.text: As agreed at Council mtg in Mov 2011, added geogName to same att classes as placeName. Implemented at  rev 9866

tickets.summary: use of head and p within figure
tickets.description: Section 14.3 \(\#FTGRA\) gives some examples of encoding captions.  While all use <head>, one uses <p> in addition to the <head>.  It's not clear what makes "Above:" different from "Figure 1:" \(or what makes the text following these different so that one should be in a separate <p> and but the other shouldn't\).  The presence of a period \(full stop\), presumably transcribed from the source document, seems like a red herring since the caption itself is just a bit longer but not syntactically different from the shorter captions.  Please offer some clarification.

posts.text: I don't think this is a bug. It sounds more like a usability discussion, which perhaps should be taking place on TEI-L. The point is that a <figure> can contain bits of text which one might want to distinguish from the heading pure and simple. The discussion at FTGRA seems quite clear to me, though I agree that "Above:" is not much of a heading. Perhaps we just need a better example \(though this one is sanctioned by history...\)
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #261 use of head and p within figure

posts.text: - **milestone**:  --> GREEN
posts.author: louburnard
posts.subject: #261 use of head and p within figure

posts.text:
My apologies: I have been meaning to get back to this since July.

If I understand Lou correctly, when he says, "The point is that a <figure>
can contain bits of text which one might want to distinguish from the
heading pure and simple.", he means that these bits of text should be encoded with <p> or <ab type="caption">, whereas "the heading" is a heading for the figure, which would be encoded with <head>.

The problem is that it's not clear what a heading for a figure is.  Sometimes it includes the whole caption, sometimes just a lead-in word like "Above:", and sometimes nothing.  I don't oppose taking this to TEI-L, and I only suggested it here because, often enough in such cases, Lou explains what he means by this or that element and then we clarify the Guidelines accordingly.  So in this case this, I'm not sure whether to ask the community what a head for a figure is or whether Council should first offer a suggested revision and then ask for community input on that.
posts.author: kshawkin
posts.subject: #261 use of head and p within figure

posts.text: I agree with Lou, this is not a bug, but a more general TEI discussion. I think the status should be set to pending.
posts.author: rahtz
posts.subject: #261 use of head and p within figure

posts.text: The example still seems pretty clear to me, but I have added a bit more to the text to clarify it further, and am setting this ticket to pending at Sebastian's suggestion, in case Kevin wants to propose a new/additional example.
